subject: proliant-tools: add net-tools package to support hpsum utility
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 7118, 'name': 'Ian Wienand', 'email': 'iwienand@redhat.com', 'username': 'iwienand'}, {'_account_id': 10118, 'name': 'IBM PowerKVM CI', 'email': 'kvmpower@linux.vnet.ibm.com', 'username': 'powerkvm', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 11076, 'name': 'Shivanand Tendulker', 'email': 'stendulker@gmail.com', 'username': 'stendulker'}, {'_account_id': 11297, 'name': 'Nisha Agarwal', 'email': 'agarwalnisha1980@gmail.com', 'username': 'Nisha'}, {'_account_id': 12898, 'name': 'Tony Breeds', 'email': 'tony@bakeyournoodle.com', 'username': 'tonyb'}, {'_account_id': 18781, 'name': 'vinay50muddu', 'email': 'vinay50muddu@yahoo.com', 'username': 'vmud213'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22977, 'name': 'Anshul Jain', 'email': 'theanshuljain@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaianshu'}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 22977, 'date': '2018-02-27 06:23:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 22977, 'date': '2018-02-27 08:40:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-02-27 10:27:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 22977, 'date': '2018-03-08 05:29:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Yes, ubuntu/debian has this package. I didn't found this on rhel base image that I got from redhat portal. So this is just a check if its is not there in the base rhel image, it will install."}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-03-08 05:57:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Yes, ubuntu/debian has this package. I didn't found this on rhel
 > base image that I got from redhat portal. So this is just a check
 > if its is not there in the base rhel image, it will install.

So your explanation doesn't match the code.

Ubuntu and EL7 both have a net-tools package called "net-tools" see links below.  If you're installing proliant-tools you need that package regardless of distro, however your change only installs it on RedHat.  Now if you got lucky and other distros installed it already things will still work but that seems fragile.

I *think* we want to always install it if we're installing the proliant-tools element, so I think adding it to package-installs and omitting it from pkg-map is the correct thing to do here

https://git.centos.org/summary/?r=rpms/net-tools.git
https://packages.ubuntu.com/xenial/net-tools'}, {'account_id': 22977, 'date': '2018-03-09 04:29:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> > Yes, ubuntu/debian has this package. I didn't found this on rhel
 > > base image that I got from redhat portal. So this is just a check
 > > if its is not there in the base rhel image, it will install.
 > 
 > So your explanation doesn't match the code.
 > 
 > Ubuntu and EL7 both have a net-tools package called "net-tools" see
 > links below.  If you're installing proliant-tools you need that
 > package regardless of distro, however your change only installs it
 > on RedHat.  Now if you got lucky and other distros installed it
 > already things will still work but that seems fragile.
 > 
 > I *think* we want to always install it if we're installing the
 > proliant-tools element, so I think adding it to package-installs
 > and omitting it from pkg-map is the correct thing to do here
 > 
 > https://git.centos.org/summary/?r=rpms/net-tools.git
 > https://packages.ubuntu.com/xenial/net-tools

Thanks for suggestion. Yes, having 'net-tools' for all distros seems to be a good solution. Updating the patch.'}, {'account_id': 22977, 'date': '2018-03-09 04:31:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-03-09 05:09:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Looks good apart from the stuff about the satellite setup that the reason for the -1'}, {'account_id': 22977, 'date': '2018-03-09 06:11:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> (3 comments)
 > 
 > Looks good apart from the stuff about the satellite setup that the
 > reason for the -1

Hi Tony, I didn't understand why change is required in rhel-common for this? 'rhel-common' is for OS installation and registration not any particular package.
I think, i will require to update the commit message to say it is not for redhat image in particular but applies to all distros. Right?"}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-03-09 06:39:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> > (3 comments)
 > >
 > > Looks good apart from the stuff about the satellite setup that
 > the
 > > reason for the -1
 > 
 > Hi Tony, I didn't understand why change is required in rhel-common
 > for this? 'rhel-common' is for OS installation and registration not
 > any particular package.
 > I think, i will require to update the commit message to say it is
 > not for redhat image in particular but applies to all distros.
 > Right?

I think that's right.  I though the rhel-common stuff some how got added from https://review.openstack.org/547255 and shouldn't be here.

Or did I misunderstand something?

Then just remove the words " for redhat based images" from the commit message'}, {'account_id': 22977, 'date': '2018-03-09 08:07:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 22977, 'date': '2018-03-09 08:28:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Published edit on patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 22977, 'date': '2018-03-09 08:29:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 18781, 'date': '2018-03-13 08:14:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Thanks Anshul for the patch. LGTM except for a comment in line.'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-03-13 09:06:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-03-13 09:07:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

Thanks for sticking with me!'}, {'account_id': 11297, 'date': '2018-03-15 12:48:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

LGTM. But i have a query Anshul, will hpsum install successfully on ubuntu/fedora?'}, {'account_id': 11076, 'date': '2018-03-15 15:30:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

Thank you Anshul.
@Nisha: HPSUM is officially supported only on RHEL and SLES [1].
https://support.hpe.com/hpsc/swd/public/detail?sp4ts.oid=1008862656&swItemId=MTX_043d47a8037c461799eb492e46&swEnvOid=4184'}, {'account_id': 22977, 'date': '2018-03-16 04:17:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

@Nisha, we are mounting SPP iso and then execute the hpsum utility after extracting. Hpsum utility is not installed as part of the image but we need to take care of its dependency(net-tools) at the time when we install proliantutils itself.'}, {'account_id': 18781, 'date': '2018-03-16 08:57:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

I have updated the comment and hope that will not impact any functionality. So upvoting.'}, {'account_id': 11297, 'date': '2018-03-16 11:43:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

@Shiv, I know that hpsum is supported officially only on RHEL and SLES thats why i asked the query because the package "net-tools" is not installed only for either of these, we are even installing it for other distros.

@Anshul, if it should be taken care at the time of installing proliantutils, then the ideal place where this dependency should go should be in proliantutils IMO. WDYT?'}, {'account_id': 22977, 'date': '2018-03-19 05:17:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> @Shiv, I know that hpsum is supported officially only on RHEL and
 > SLES thats why i asked the query because the package "net-tools" is
 > not installed only for either of these, we are even installing it
 > for other distros.
 > 
 > @Anshul, if it should be taken care at the time of installing
 > proliantutils, then the ideal place where this dependency should go
 > should be in proliantutils IMO. WDYT?

We need net-tools binaries here and not python library. So it needs to be installed here only rather than in proliantutils requirements.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-03-22 23:47:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

It's not clear to me a consensus has been reached on this yet?  Can someone summarise if this ok or not?"}, {'account_id': 22977, 'date': '2018-03-23 04:32:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

@Ian, to summarize this patch does not requires any changes and as per DIB guidelines it is the correct place to add this utility. The queries have been addressed and I feel the patch is good to go in.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-03-23 04:48:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]

commit_message:
proliant-tools: add net-tools package to support hpsum utility

Hpsum utiltity of proliant-tools requires net-tools to be installed
as part of base image. This commit adds support for installation of
net-tools for all distros.

Change-Id: I2a1e81059ed1aee975db78cfa5e61bbf1b98e06f
Closes-bug: 1751777

commit_message:
Configure memcache_secret_key as secret

Parameter keystone_authtoken/metadata_proxy_shared_secret should be
configured as a secret.

Change-Id: I74afaf85569b4ba756f4ca82f822e481f80253b6
Closes-Bug: #1756813

commit_message:
Add replace cold migration to use nova API spec

This patch adds replace-cold-migrate-to-use-nova-migration-api spec.

Implements: blueprint replace-cold-migrate-to-use-nova-migration-api
Change-Id: Ib83d391fe2cb2ba63a1ce20ec39011dbb0755a35

- nova-dsvm-full-tempest http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/549789/2/ : SUCCESS in 2h 10m 32s'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-05 23:45:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck infra'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2018-03-06 01:55:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Build succeeded.

- nova-dsvm-full-tempest http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/549789/2/ : SUCCESS in 2h 09m 29s'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-06 02:10:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

15 tests failed:

http://logs.openstack.org/89/549789/2/check/nova-cells-v1/965072f/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-03-06_01_01_17_478719

At first glance, some of these are simply things that don't work with cells v1 and neutron because the APIs plumbing wasn't done for cells v1. There are some other things in here that just won't work because they rely on things that aren't in the cells v1 API, like support for security groups. I do remember that at one point Chuck Carmack was working on adding configuration options to Tempest to skip tests that relied on security groups so we could configure and skip things globally, but that was all caught up in some review debate and abandoned, so we'll likely just have to skip those tests in our blacklist file."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-08 23:09:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2018-03-09 00:27:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I see the problem in tempest.scenario.test_network_advanced_server_ops.TestNetworkAdvancedServerOps.test_server_connectivity_reboot - the test is creating a floating IP based on the port for the server, but the port isn't yet ACTIVE. Normally we'd wait for the vif to be plugged before the server is ACTIVE, but we're not waiting for that here, so the server goes to ACTIVE before the vif is fully plugged and the port is changed to ACTIVE. We could add some wait code to this test in tempest to wait for the port to be ACTIVE, but it's probably easier to just skip the test as it's going to be a known race."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-14 16:12:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2018-03-14 18:17:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

commit_message:
Make nova-cells-v1 run with neutron

This changes the nova-cells-v1 job to run with neutron instead
of nova-network.

SSH validation is already disabled in Tempest for this job.

Since the os-server-external-events API is not plumbed in for
cells v1, we have to disable vif plugging settings in
nova-cells.conf. This means servers will be ACTIVE before
networking is sure to be ready so we can't rely on ssh validation.

We also configure Tempest to say floating IPs aren't available
which skips several scenario tests that wouldn't work with cells v1
anyway due to them trying to ssh into the guest.

Part of blueprint remove-nova-network

Change-Id: I9de6b710baffdffcd1d7ab19897d5776ef27ae7e

in congress

commit_message:
Make tenant_name as optional config option

Currently, tenant_name is marked as required config option, and doesnt
accept if only project_name is provided. As tenant_name usage is deprecated by
keystone, this commit makes project_name as required attribute instead.

But for backward-compatibility, if tenant_name provided, no error would be
raised, but a warning message would be logged.

Change-Id: I48ca316810f572fc5f932d898b9bd837f726da7a
Closes-Bug:#1748860

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: I6c115612ac6ee56f2199c654a844fed8723ca666
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

rather than the stable/pike version for local testing.

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-06-16 09:45:19.000000000', 'message': 'Integrate OSprofiler in Ceilometer

* Add osprofiler wsgi middleware. This middleware is used for 2 things:
  1) It checks that person who wants to trace is trusted and knows
     secret HMAC key.
  2) It starts tracing in case of proper trace headers
     and adds first wsgi trace point, with info about HTTP request

* Traces HTTP API calls

HOW TO TEST?

1. Install devstack with ceilometer as usual

2. Install osprofiler

    pip install osprofiler

3. Add these line to /etc/ceilometer/ceilometer.conf

   [profiler]
   enabled = true
   hmac_keys = SECRET_KEY
   connection_string = redis://localhost:6379 # example when using redis

4. Use ceilometer client to call a command with `--profile <HMAC_KEYS>`
Output will look like this:

To display trace use the command:

  osprofiler trace show --html <TRACE_ID>

5. Use osprofiler to get the trace

    osprofiler trace show \
        --connection-string redis://localhost:6379 \
        --out out.html \
        --html <TRACE_ID>

Related patch (in ceilometer client): I36f0899fe9a52333326943df8b5a606dc272ec52
Spec: https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/oslo-specs/specs/mitaka/osprofiler-cross-service-project-profiling.html
OSprofiler doc: https://docs.openstack.org/developer/osprofiler

Depends-On: I82e0db75ef9f84075289e360428c09ec68fb72d9

Change-Id: I23b32adf2a055ac197cbfa8546207018c255b881

commit_message:
Integrate OSprofiler in Ceilometer

* Add osprofiler wsgi middleware. This middleware is used for 2 things:
  1) It checks that person who wants to trace is trusted and knows
     secret HMAC key.
  2) It starts tracing in case of proper trace headers
     and adds first wsgi trace point, with info about HTTP request

* Traces HTTP API calls

HOW TO TEST?

1. Install devstack with ceilometer as usual

2. Install osprofiler

    pip install osprofiler

3. Add these line to /etc/ceilometer/ceilometer.conf

   [profiler]
   enabled = true
   hmac_keys = SECRET_KEY
   connection_string = redis://localhost:6379 # example when using redis

4. Use ceilometer client to call a command with `--profile <HMAC_KEYS>`
Output will look like this:

To display trace use the command:

  osprofiler trace show --html <TRACE_ID>

5. Use osprofiler to get the trace

    osprofiler trace show \
        --connection-string redis://localhost:6379 \
        --out out.html \
        --html <TRACE_ID>

Related patch (in ceilometer client): I36f0899fe9a52333326943df8b5a606dc272ec52
Spec: https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/oslo-specs/specs/mitaka/osprofiler-cross-service-project-profiling.html
OSprofiler doc: https://docs.openstack.org/developer/osprofiler

Co-Authored-By: Hieu LE <hieulq@vn.fujitsu.com>

Depends-On: I82e0db75ef9f84075289e360428c09ec68fb72d9

Change-Id: I23b32adf2a055ac197cbfa8546207018c255b881

[{'created': '2018-03-22 10:04:50.000000000', 'message': 'Checking if the overcloud group is empty

The hostnamemap_override fact is failing in featureset027 because the
group overcloud is empty, and hostnamemap_override forces to access the
first object from this group. This patch add one more verification
before setting the fact.

Change-Id: Ibe459b3200d8eaeb93171955f16dbb64dc077a33
Closes-Bug: 1757474
'}]
commit_message:
Checking if the overcloud group is empty

The hostnamemap_override fact is failing in featureset027 because the
group overcloud is empty, and hostnamemap_override forces to access the
first object from this group. This patch add one more verification
before setting the fact.

Change-Id: Ibe459b3200d8eaeb93171955f16dbb64dc077a33
Closes-Bug: 1757474

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: Ib098a5cd8e4d119bea61d9b6c28d8274902fe4fd
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Add nova-cells-v1 to experimental queue jobs

The legacy-tempest-dsvm-cells job is being moved into the
nova repo and renamed to nova-cells-v1. This change adds
the new job name to the in-tree definition of the experimental
queue jobs that run on devstack changes. A project-config change
will depend on this patch to undefine the legacy job name from
being used on devstack changes.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/549780
Change-Id: I22fa1411809c46ffc423e0dd1cde0d8f40362635

commit_message:
Migrate tempest-dsvm-cells job to an in-tree job definition

This defines the nova-cells-v1 job, based the tempest-dsvm-cells
job from openstack-zuul-jobs.

The branch override parts of the job definition are removed since
the job will be defined per-branch now (we'll also have to backport
this to stable/queens).

There will be related changes to project-config, devstack, tempest
and openstack-zuul-jobs on this topic branch to use the new job name.

Part of blueprint remove-nova-network

Change-Id: I25c87f27c69e0cdb74e8553305a09cb85f43d87e

[{'created': '2018-03-20 21:27:21.000000000', 'message': "Install tripleo-common from source

I was trying to test a depends-on change for tripleo-common, but it
doesn't install from the zuul checkout.  Do this alongside dib.

Change-Id: I72cab0131ccffb1989d6c1324d0c9b92166782da
"}, {'created': '2018-03-21 01:41:49.000000000', 'message': "Install tripleo-common from source

This test currently installs tripleo-common from pypi.  This can cause
problems; for example I1e64647b3de86bc87a2a04cedf54ac83bbd4963d added
config options to the yaml files (which *are* used directly from the
tripleo-common zuul-cloned tree) and a related code change; but the
code change isn't deployed and we get failures parsing the config.

Also, it means you can't depends-on tripleo-common changes in
dib/python-tripleoclient.

Install it alongside the zuul-cloned dib install.

Closes-Bug: #1757174
Change-Id: I72cab0131ccffb1989d6c1324d0c9b92166782da
"}]
commit_message:
Install tripleo-common from source

This test currently installs tripleo-common from pypi.  This can cause
problems; for example I1e64647b3de86bc87a2a04cedf54ac83bbd4963d added
config options to the yaml files (which *are* used directly from the
tripleo-common zuul-cloned tree) and a related code change; but the
code change isn't deployed and we get failures parsing the config.

Also, it means you can't depends-on tripleo-common changes in
dib/python-tripleoclient.

Install it alongside the zuul-cloned dib install.

Closes-Bug: #1757174
Change-Id: I72cab0131ccffb1989d6c1324d0c9b92166782da

When I ran `python setup.py install` with this patch, I got:

running install_data
creating /usr/etc/barbican
copying etc/barbican/barbican-api-paste.ini -> /usr/etc/barbican
copying etc/barbican/policy.json -> /usr/etc/barbican

The files were copied to /usr/etc/barbican, is this normal?'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2017-09-25 13:53:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Jeremy Yes, that's normal. Your action is to install into the /usr space. The install will put them into a relative path. For example, if you install into a venv, the files go into the venv /etc directory, not the system /etc directory."}, {'account_id': 21797, 'date': '2017-09-25 14:26:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

OK, this affects a non-voting gate job, but it should be fine. RDO community may figure this out and make corresponding changes for our packaging project. Looks good to me.

https://github.com/rdo-packages/barbican-distgit/blob/rpm-master/openstack-barbican.spec#L161'}, {'account_id': 21797, 'date': '2017-09-25 15:41:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Jesse Pretorius (odyssey4me),

Is there any existing use case of this patch, i.e., how would this benefit installation from source? I saw this merged into nova, but RDO community removed this from spec file as it breaks packaging. https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/c/9736/

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2017-09-25 16:14:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Jeremy Yes, the OpenStack-Ansible project will be using these files. Currently we have to either vendor them into the Ansible roles or download them from git at runtime. With this inclusion we will be able to use the contents of the wheel instead which is far simpler.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2017-10-03 13:02:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Add default configuration files to data_files

In order to make it simpler to use the default
configuration files when deploying services
from source, the files are added to pbr's
data_files section so that the files are
included in the built wheels and therefore
deployed with the code. Packaging and deployment
tools can then more easily use the default files
if they wish to.

This pattern is already established with similar
files for neutron and the glance metadefs as has
been mentioned in the related bug report.

Change-Id: Iacb17585a3235e95faa109ff11f1b039429ff770
Closes-Bug: #1718356

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-21 21:14:57.000000000', 'message': "Don't try to delete build request during a reschedule

If populate_retry failed because of MaxRetriesExceeded,
don't try to delete build requests because they should
already be gone from the initial create attempt, plus
we should assume the cell conductor can't reach the API
database anyway.

Similar for hitting NoValidHost during a reschedule. We
can tell if we're doing a reschedule by the num_attempts
value in filter_properties, populated via populate_retry,
which will be >1 during a reschedule.

Change-Id: I0b3ec6bb098ca32ffd32a61d4f9dcf426c3faf46
Closes-Bug: #1736946
(cherry picked from commit cf88a27c6250043859306d47ae82a63535ad507f)
(cherry picked from commit 96acf3db0bc9ecaddb04fc9effc4b9ca1553103d)
"}]
commit_message:
Don't try to delete build request during a reschedule

If populate_retry failed because of MaxRetriesExceeded,
don't try to delete build requests because they should
already be gone from the initial create attempt, plus
we should assume the cell conductor can't reach the API
database anyway.

Similar for hitting NoValidHost during a reschedule. We
can tell if we're doing a reschedule by the num_attempts
value in filter_properties, populated via populate_retry,
which will be >1 during a reschedule.

Change-Id: I0b3ec6bb098ca32ffd32a61d4f9dcf426c3faf46
Closes-Bug: #1736946
(cherry picked from commit cf88a27c6250043859306d47ae82a63535ad507f)
(cherry picked from commit 96acf3db0bc9ecaddb04fc9effc4b9ca1553103d)

commit_message:
Add default configuration files to data_files

In order to make it simpler to use the default
configuration files when deploying services
from source, the files are added to pbr's
data_files section so that the files are
included in the built wheels and therefore
deployed with the code. Packaging and deployment
tools can then more easily use the default files
if they wish to.

This pattern is already established with similar
files for neutron and the glance metadefs as has
been mentioned in the related bug report.

Change-Id: I42f4279665183fbe65d85a2d53af269d1f37b13a
Closes-Bug: #1718356

[{'account_id': 21151, 'date': '2018-03-07 05:34:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 18575, 'date': '2018-03-07 06:19:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6133, 'date': '2018-03-07 07:24:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 21151, 'date': '2018-03-07 08:28:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

CI job failed with:
---------------------------------------------------------
2018-03-07 06:50:05 |  u'message': u"Failed to run action [action_ex_id=6a99bb51-c2dd-4567-9b7c-76971a08f0c5, action_cls='<class 'mistral.actions.action_factory.DeployStackAction'>', attributes='{}', params='{u'skip_deploy_identifier': False, u'container': u'overcloud', u'timeout': 97}']\n ERROR: Property error: : resources.AllNodesDeploySteps<http://192.168.24.1:8080/v1/AUTH_ca55815652d04eecb97e6882521af796/overcloud/common/post.yaml>.resources.ControllerExtraConfigPost.properties: : Unknown Property name",
2018-03-07 06:50:05 |  u'status': u'FAILED'}
---------------------------------------------------------

this may due to the default 'OS::TripleO::NodeExtraConfig' is set to 'puppet/extraconfig/pre_deploy/default.yaml' which is not a OS::Heat::SoftwareDeployment type.

setting 'OS::TripleO::NodeExtraConfig' to 'OS::Heat::None' type.'}, {'account_id': 21151, 'date': '2018-03-07 08:29:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-03-07 16:55:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

CI failure looks real http://logs.openstack.org/34/550334/2/check/tripleo-ci-centos-7-undercloud-containers/e799242/logs/undercloud/home/zuul/undercloud_install.log.txt.gz#_2018-03-07_08_54_44 ?'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-03-07 16:56:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 21151, 'date': '2018-03-08 01:35:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-03-08 09:43:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 21151, 'date': '2018-03-09 13:42:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

looking at the HEAT doc, I realized this might be a wrong way to go by configuring name properties of {Pre|Post}Config and ExtraConfigPost. Because these types will(have to) be defined by users to pass customized config/deployment, each type will contain both a SoftwareConfig and a SoftwareDeployment which the name property shall be attached to.

Also it's not possible to set {Pre|Post}Config or ExtraConfigPost as a deployment type which in turn may have a name property. the reason is that these configurations are really user specific, we cannot extract a common deployment resource to cover all the possibilities.

To avoid the problem mentioned in commit message, user has to explicitly set the name property for deployment resource."}, {'account_id': 8449, 'date': '2018-03-12 08:31:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 21151, 'date': '2018-03-13 00:59:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 21151, 'date': '2018-03-23 01:59:45.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Abandoning the patch as the original problem will be solved with the following commits:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/552274/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/554614/'}]

commit_message:
Set name property on the Deployment resources

Deployment_name is used in tripleo-common to
generate ansible playbooks. If it's None, it
will default to the name of parent_resource.
This patch is going to add name properties to
PreConfig, ExtraConfigPost and PostConfig
resources in case name property is not set in
customized templates.

Change-Id: Id262c75aa1483ca2507c6106bbeff2e9e3f0e682

[{'created': '2017-11-07 11:53:33.000000000', 'message': 'Run backup compression on native thread

Backup data compression is a CPU bound operation that will not yield to
other greenthreads, so given enough simultaneous backup operations they
will lead to other threads' starvation.

This is really problematic for DB connections, since starvation will
lead to connections getting dropped with errors such as "Lost connection
to MySQL server during query".

Detailed information on why these connections get dropped can be found
in comment "[31 Aug 2007 9:21] Magnus Blåudd" on this MySQL bug [1].

These DB issues may result in backups unnecessary ending in an "error"
state.

This patch fixes this by moving the compression to a native thread so
the cooperative multitasking in Cinder Backup can continue switching
threads.

[1] https://bugs.mysql.com/bug.php?id=28359

Closes-Bug: #1692775
Closes-Bug: #1719580
Change-Id: I1946dc0ad9cb7a68072a39816fa9fa224c2eb6a5
(cherry picked from commit af0f00bc52f79d9395adfe0575b0dbe353e18bbe)
(cherry picked from commit 439f90da8e4c1cfa1acfe36b5ea8a6c5bae6139f)
'}]
commit_message:
Run backup compression on native thread

Backup data compression is a CPU bound operation that will not yield to
other greenthreads, so given enough simultaneous backup operations they
will lead to other threads' starvation.

This is really problematic for DB connections, since starvation will
lead to connections getting dropped with errors such as "Lost connection
to MySQL server during query".

Detailed information on why these connections get dropped can be found
in comment "[31 Aug 2007 9:21] Magnus Blåudd" on this MySQL bug [1].

These DB issues may result in backups unnecessary ending in an "error"
state.

This patch fixes this by moving the compression to a native thread so
the cooperative multitasking in Cinder Backup can continue switching
threads.

[1] https://bugs.mysql.com/bug.php?id=28359

Closes-Bug: #1692775
Closes-Bug: #1719580
Change-Id: I1946dc0ad9cb7a68072a39816fa9fa224c2eb6a5
(cherry picked from commit af0f00bc52f79d9395adfe0575b0dbe353e18bbe)
(cherry picked from commit 439f90da8e4c1cfa1acfe36b5ea8a6c5bae6139f)

[{'created': '2018-03-16 10:10:05.000000000', 'message': 'Make archive_deleted_rows handle a missing CONF.api_database.connection

This change https://review.openstack.org/#/c/515034/ (added in queens)
makes the archive_deleted_rows CLI remove instance mappings and request
specs from the API database if there are instances archived from the
main nova/cell database. However for this to work, the api database
connection should be set in the config file. So in the case that the
API database is not configured in the config file being used to run the
CLI, we should gracefully handle the condition and and stop archiving thus
prompting the user to set the api_db config and try the archival operation
again. This patch fixes the graceful handling.

Conflicts:
    nova/tests/unit/test_nova_manage.py

NOTE(tssurya): The conflict is due to not having changes
I6f87cf03d49be6bfad2c5e6f0c8accf0fab4e6ee and
Ibd824a77b32cbceb60973a89a93ce09fe6d1050d in Queens.

Change-Id: I0c7b802a453aa423c7273ab724ce78eac0cfed4c
Closes-Bug: #1753833
(cherry picked from commit 8da6831e6375d013f0235a542b6b91580a43f61f)
'}]
commit_message:
Make archive_deleted_rows handle a missing CONF.api_database.connection

This change https://review.openstack.org/#/c/515034/ (added in queens)
makes the archive_deleted_rows CLI remove instance mappings and request
specs from the API database if there are instances archived from the
main nova/cell database. However for this to work, the api database
connection should be set in the config file. So in the case that the
API database is not configured in the config file being used to run the
CLI, we should gracefully handle the condition and and stop archiving thus
prompting the user to set the api_db config and try the archival operation
again. This patch fixes the graceful handling.

Conflicts:
    nova/tests/unit/test_nova_manage.py

NOTE(tssurya): The conflict is due to not having changes
I6f87cf03d49be6bfad2c5e6f0c8accf0fab4e6ee and
Ibd824a77b32cbceb60973a89a93ce09fe6d1050d in Queens.

Change-Id: I0c7b802a453aa423c7273ab724ce78eac0cfed4c
Closes-Bug: #1753833
(cherry picked from commit 8da6831e6375d013f0235a542b6b91580a43f61f)

remove mitmproxy

mitmproxt is only used by mitmstack and rpm-packaging, both of which
we do not care about.

"}, {'created': '2018-02-10 18:28:27.000000000', 'message': "Handle URL reconstruction in PEP333 compatible fashion

The Pecan url in wsgi forward scenarios is not correct, as
it does not handle the extra headers injected by the forwarding
handler. Improve this to properly detect the https case in
case the loadbalancer terminates SSL as well and always return
the original's request HOST for consistency.

Change-Id: I3a208abbc6134d1c7be245d35eb4564ef886bd9b
"}]
commit_message:
Handle URL reconstruction in PEP333 compatible fashion

The Pecan url in wsgi forward scenarios is not correct, as
it does not handle the extra headers injected by the forwarding
handler. Improve this to properly detect the https case in
case the loadbalancer terminates SSL as well and always return
the original's request HOST for consistency.

Change-Id: I3a208abbc6134d1c7be245d35eb4564ef886bd9b

commit_message:
Require own_shard_range to be in sharding state before sharding db

Before, it was assumed that if a broker had shard ranges then it would
have an own_shard_range and have epoch metadata. It was either
bootstrapped by a leader action, or its shard ranges and metadata were
replicated from another node where it had been bootstrapped by a
leader.

To support shard ranges being manually injected, we must either
bootstrap one to sharding state or we require that the injected shard
ranges include an own_shard_range. The first approach risks two nodes
finding shard ranges, creating own_shard_range and choosing different
epochs.

This patch therefore takes the latter approach of requiring
own_shard_range to exist in sharding, shrinking or sharded state
before the sharding process will begin, even if other shard ranges
exist. Note that sharded state is included because another node may
have completed sharded and progressed own_shard_range state before
another node.

A following patch adds epoch to ShardRange's thus ensuring that an
own_shard_range will have an epoch.

Change-Id: Ib6e87bc00a08dbb1921fbeb53393ee51e5989265

commit_message:
Bump lower bound of requests-mock

The lower-constraints job added to shade has identified that
requests-mock 1.1.0 is unable to run shade's unit tests. 1.2.0 is fine.

Change-Id: Iff2f3a95667f0be96ee1fa5a0c5bb417e9970551

[{'created': '2018-03-22 22:44:47.000000000', 'message': 'add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: Ib54727bef315518ebcb6e5554911f3e76651e4c7
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: Ib54727bef315518ebcb6e5554911f3e76651e4c7
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Fix vhd image conversion regression

A recent change introduced a regression: due to a wrong assignment,
we're no longer passing qemu-img the right format when converting
images to "vhd". Note that it expects the legacy "vpc" name.

This change addresses this issue.

Closes-Bug: #1757244

Change-Id: If7a2e3470403b45eff69dcf69b67615bb982a4eb

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-22 06:14:41.000000000', 'message': 'Fix ipv6 certificate to make it compliant with IDNA

Currently we are setting "DNS.0 = ::1", but ::1 is not a valid
A-Label for IDNA so the certificate is not correct.

Additionally, we are setting wrong value for DNS.0 = 127.0.0.1
in the ipv4 certificate.

Finally, removing issuerAltName from both ipv4 and ipv6 certificates
as they are not needed for the jobs.

New versions of python-cryptography are more strict to check
certificates content and does not allow to have not compliant
DNS names so we need to fix the certificate to bump python-cryptography.

Note that horizont tempest plugin does not support ipaddress SANs based
certificate validation so I'm disablint certificate validation for
dashboard in this patch.

Depends-On: Iea7a4b85ac64572fac0f0ad871649a79fbc1c0f5

Change-Id: Ib519d222e07e26d3683b24359e2f67728cdd8029
(cherry picked from commit e40e6d934bb01e0ff1881b3fee92d97d17437179)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix ipv6 certificate to make it compliant with IDNA

Currently we are setting "DNS.0 = ::1", but ::1 is not a valid
A-Label for IDNA so the certificate is not correct.

Additionally, we are setting wrong value for DNS.0 = 127.0.0.1
in the ipv4 certificate.

Finally, removing issuerAltName from both ipv4 and ipv6 certificates
as they are not needed for the jobs.

New versions of python-cryptography are more strict to check
certificates content and does not allow to have not compliant
DNS names so we need to fix the certificate to bump python-cryptography.

Note that horizont tempest plugin does not support ipaddress SANs based
certificate validation so I'm disablint certificate validation for
dashboard in this patch.

Depends-On: Iea7a4b85ac64572fac0f0ad871649a79fbc1c0f5

Change-Id: Ib519d222e07e26d3683b24359e2f67728cdd8029
(cherry picked from commit e40e6d934bb01e0ff1881b3fee92d97d17437179)

commit_message:
Do not fail on stackviz issues

The process-stackviz role only helps with analyzing runs, when it fails
it should not cause the whole job to suffer a POST_FAILURE.

Change-Id: Icfd6b2fc7adb42afb7900ea4458fa60cefc76fdb
Related-Bug: 1758054

commit_message:
Fix db migration for mariadb >= 10.2.8

Starting with mariadb 10.2.8, removing a column
that is part of a primary key requires that the
primary key constraint be dropped and recreated.

Change-Id: I43e4dae325dd6561a9fe0fd4ce595cea4c2ef7a6
Closes-Bug: #1749184
(cherry picked from commit 4a40da15fe0e9688c363371fd998ef7c3ba321ee)

commit_message:
Fix nits in the XClarity Driver codebase.

Follow up to commit 346a9a3bfc5312deb78bda8a82ae238e031413bd

 * Move exception XClarityError to common/exceptions.py
 * Update language of the release note.
 * Specify the kind of power operation being performed.

Change-Id: I1dbc49d7d6185ce3c5f37f518bbecd11571a74fb

commit_message:
Give sharder send_ranges its own GreenAsyncPile

We only need to wait for the put requests that send_ranges spawns, not
every thread in a shared pool.

Change-Id: Ie21f85c7d98a705d91422c0d8f5242a9193e6513

commit_message:
Add specs folder for Qinling

We don't need to put the specs files in a separate place to avoid
maintaince overhead, putting them in qinling's repo will also make it
easy to build qinling documenatation.

Change-Id: Ica8c68c6f15f97231a87e9e82fdf2d7e475a6e03

commit_message:
Split the container and host variable files

The host and container image variable files have been split. This split
now gives deployers the ability to change or customize the container
image used on a given host.

Change-Id: I839bbcfff3f33dde144e9fb8d078fa1d97f8c410
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-17 18:39:29.000000000', 'message': "Convert lxc_hosts role to use simple download URL

For a very long time we've been parsing and using the lxc images as
provided by upstream lxc. While these images are functional there are by
no means optimal. In general they're quite a bit larger than they need
to be and contian a lot of little sharp edges that have cut us over
time. This change removes all of the lxc image cache parsing and
meta-data linking and simply downloads the rootfs from our supported
stable distros. At present the image for ubuntu is consuming the base
rootfs orovided by canonical. The opensuse image is coming from the suse
cloud images repo. The centos image is provided by centos openstack
images.

The result of this change:

* Smaller more optimal base image which is well known by the corresponding
  communities.

* Deployers now have the ability to set and forget the download url for an
  internal image instead of having to create a cache infrastructure
  compatible with the lxc download template.

* Few tasks are executed and less memory is consumed resulting in faster
  deployment times.

* The base cache has a uniform meta-data setup giving all container
  types the same access to config, devices, and templating.

Change-Id: I1775e775bbb7fe86bdffdd8296c2cff5ebc5bac8
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

"}, {'created': '2018-03-18 04:09:54.000000000', 'message': "Convert lxc_hosts role to use simple download URL

For a very long time we've been parsing and using the lxc images as
provided by upstream lxc. While these images are functional there are by
no means optimal. In general they're quite a bit larger than they need
to be and contian a lot of little sharp edges that have cut us over
the years. This change removes all of the lxc image cache parsing and
meta-data linking and simply downloads the rootfs a given url. To
maintain compatibility with the legacy images a script has been created
to parse the image index and return the legacy image url.

The result of this change:

* Smaller more optimal base image which is well known by the corresponding
  communities.

* Deployers now have the ability to set and forget the download url for an
  internal image instead of having to create a cache infrastructure
  compatible with the lxc download template.

* Any rootfs tarball will work as an image.

* Fewer tasks are executed and less memory is consumed resulting in faster
  deployment times.

* The base cache has a uniform meta-data setup giving all container
  types the same access to config, devices, and templating.

Change-Id: I1775e775bbb7fe86bdffdd8296c2cff5ebc5bac8
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

the years. This change removes all of the lxc image cache parsing and
meta-data linking and simply downloads the rootfs a given url. To
maintain compatibility with the legacy images a script has been created
to parse the image index and return the legacy image url.

The result of this change:

* Access to smaller more optimal base image which is well known by the
  corresponding communities.

* Deployers now have the ability to set and forget the download url for an
  internal image instead of having to create a cache infrastructure
  compatible with the lxc download template.

* Any rootfs tarball will work as an image.

* Fewer tasks are executed and less memory is consumed resulting in faster
  deployment times.

* The base cache has a uniform meta-data setup giving all container
  types the same access to config, devices, and templating.

Change-Id: I1775e775bbb7fe86bdffdd8296c2cff5ebc5bac8
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Convert lxc_hosts role to use simple download URL

For a very long time we've been parsing and using the lxc images as
provided by upstream lxc. While these images are functional there are by
no means optimal. In general they're quite a bit larger than they need
to be and contian a lot of little sharp edges that have cut us over
the years. This change removes all of the lxc image cache parsing and
meta-data linking and simply downloads the rootfs a given url. To
maintain compatibility with the legacy images a script has been created
to parse the image index and return the legacy image url.

The result of this change:

* Access to smaller more optimal base image which is well known by the
  corresponding communities.

* Deployers now have the ability to set and forget the download url for an
  internal image instead of having to create a cache infrastructure
  compatible with the lxc download template.

* Any rootfs tarball will work as an image.

* Fewer tasks are executed and less memory is consumed resulting in faster
  deployment times.

* The base cache has a uniform meta-data setup giving all container
  types the same access to config, devices, and templating.

Change-Id: I1775e775bbb7fe86bdffdd8296c2cff5ebc5bac8
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

subject: oslo middleware: check puppet resource instead of actual config in spec

commit_message:
Add project_tags identity feature flag

This PS adds the project_tags identity feature flag which allows
identity v3 project tags API functionality to be enabled for
releases after Pike. Once Pike is no longer supported in Tempest
this feature flag can be removed.

Depends-On: Ibaec1df79c9ac69c65cf5075c3519092bc609546
Change-Id: Iec6b34c10ea1bd7103720c773b48ce130643115d

commit_message:
Retain the ordering when using with MultiStringOp

When using config_template with a MultiStringOp the order was subject to
change because of the use of set theory. This change converts the use of
sets to tuples which allow us to retain the ability to override options
without losing the ordering of keys.

Change-Id: Id0bba86629a33ce74528c0bd51b11183f5315d86
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Update LUN description after migration for Huawei array

This patch updates the migrated LUN's description to the original
LUN's name, which keeps the migrated LUN having the same info as
the original LUN.

Change-Id: If82043b93054eb8d15f68d8d6a368905fdb50c2a

[{'created': '2018-03-22 13:06:16.000000000', 'message': 'add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: Ifb4030c25ebc3342da15c8c903d8fd22fe743586
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

commit_message:
Adding neutron.service_plugins for "entry_points" in file "setup.cfg"

Adding neutron.service_plugins for "entry_points" in file "setup.cfg"
After Installing neutron-dynamic-routing,we need to set service_plugins for
"neutron_dynamic_routing.services.bgp.bgp_plugin.BgpPlugin" in neutron.conf.
It is more reasonable to add neutron.service_plugins for "entry_points"
in file "setup.cfg",and set "bgp" for
"neutron_dynamic_routing.services.bgp.bgp_plugin:BgpPlugin".

Change-Id: Icea1e085102e78c8bdf0e61d0b4f3f7b5ea209e2

Help text for some image properties (architecture, os_distro) is
pulled from the glanceclient's local version of the image schema.
The URL for those property definitions has gotten out of sync with

Closes-bug: #1757918
"}]
commit_message:
Update properties URL

Help text for some image properties (architecture, os_distro) is
pulled from the glanceclient's local version of the image schema.
The URL for those property definitions has gotten out of sync with
Glance.  This patch updates the URL to be the same as that given
in the Glance image-schema response.

Change-Id: I4e46e78525fe5c00e031a98c47cacc17e5693d53
Closes-bug: #1757918

For reference, I can understand why this is an option, but I think it is an abdication of responsibility to help the projects know how best to make best progress in our ecosystem.

But I agree it needs to be presented to reflect the options being considered.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-03-08 18:00:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This is OK as far as it goes.

However, project teams need a long-term-stable answer to the question of where best to put trademark tests, informed by the best technical information available to the community.

That answer does not necessarily need to be contained in a TC resolution, but putting it there would help with the long-term-stability aspect. For that reason I would prefer some variation on I2e68c8e855e7c6c1e4f985f38a0a38de451407a3 to this.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-09 09:10:54.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from test-location-option-3 to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-03-09 10:15:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

subject: Clarify testing for interop programs
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 782, 'name': 'John Garbutt', 'email': 'john@johngarbutt.com', 'username': 'johngarbutt'}, {'_account_id': 1921, 'name': 'Andrea Frittoli', 'email': 'andrea.frittoli@gmail.com', 'username': 'andrea-frittoli'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 5196, 'name': 'Matthew Treinish', 'email': 'mtreinish@kortar.org', 'username': 'treinish'}, {'_account_id': 5263, 'name': 'Jeremy Stanley', 'display_name': 'fungi', 'email': 'fungi@yuggoth.org', 'username': 'fungi', 'status': 'missing, presumed fed'}, {'_account_id': 6754, 'name': 'Mark T. Voelker', 'email': 'markvoelker@gmail.com', 'username': 'mvoelker'}, {'_account_id': 7822, 'name': 'Chris Hoge (not involved in upstream development)', 'email': 'chris@hogepodge.com', 'username': 'hogepodge'}, {'_account_id': 8099, 'name': 'Graham Hayes', 'email': 'gr@ham.ie', 'username': 'graham'}, {'_account_id': 8434, 'name': 'Rochelle Grober', 'email': 'rochelle.grober@huawei.com', 'username': 'rockyg'}, {'_account_id': 8556, 'name': 'Ghanshyam', 'display_name': 'Ghanshyam Mann', 'email': 'gmann@ghanshyammann.com', 'username': 'ghanshyam'}, {'_account_id': 11139, 'name': 'Egle', 'email': 'ushnishtha@hotmail.com', 'username': 'ushnishtha'}, {'_account_id': 11564, 'name': 'Chris Dent', 'email': 'cdent@anticdent.org', 'username': 'chdent'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 12404, 'name': 'Rico Lin', 'email': 'ricolin@ricolky.com', 'username': 'rico.lin'}, {'_account_id': 13629, 'name': 'Zhipeng', 'email': 'huangzhipeng@huawei.com', 'username': 'zhipengh'}, {'_account_id': 16353, 'name': 'Georg Kunz', 'email': 'georg.kunz@ericsson.com', 'username': 'georg-kunz'}, {'_account_id': 17716, 'name': 'Luz Cazares', 'email': 'luz.cazares@intel.com', 'username': 'luzcazares'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2017-11-20 17:35:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2017-11-20 17:47:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1 Code-Review-1

Of these options, option 1 is the only one that keeps the interop related tests in one place, something that is important for the program to be meaningful and inspectable.

There is, however, a third option that is not listed:

an interop-tempest-plugin or defcore-tempest-plugin that could be tagged with each standard, and keep a history of what we have added and removed over the years

That provides an option to have an actual thing that can be inspected and visited and viewed as a meaningful bit of "these are the interop and trademark tests" without a bunch of other cruft in the way.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2017-11-20 17:49:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Of these options, option 1 is the only one that keeps the interop
 > related tests in one place, something that is important for the
 > program to be meaningful and inspectable.
 > 
 > There is, however, a third option that is not listed:
 > 
 > an interop-tempest-plugin or defcore-tempest-plugin that could be
 > tagged with each standard, and keep a history of what we have added
 > and removed over the years
 > 
 > That provides an option to have an actual thing that can be
 > inspected and visited and viewed as a meaningful bit of "these are
 > the interop and trademark tests" without a bunch of other cruft in
 > the way.

I like option 3.

I'd be interested in understanding why the tools were built to support a different model and how hard it would be to change to option 3 or option 1.'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2017-11-20 18:14:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The tooling is "built" that way, by virtue of having the add on programs' tempest plugins being installed exposes them to the testing tooling.

For moving to Option 3, I think we would need to answer a few technical questions, and ensure that the plugin interface provides enough for the separate repo plugin to fully work.'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2017-11-20 19:18:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2017-11-20 19:37:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I actually like option 2. It's a logical fit, if you want add-on certification x you install plugin x. I think the interop team likes option 2 too, specifically because it provides a clean split between the powered programs and add-ons.  I know some people's feathers get ruffled by saying x is tested by default and y is an optional extra thing, but it is a model that actually reflects usage of openstack projects, especially for what the interop program is doing.

For option 3 the fundamental issue with creating a separate plugin is it doesn't actually fix anything except some peoples' perceptions about what is viewed as important and it actually makes a lot of things worse for users and maintainers. Tempest will not be splitting it's repo again to split library functions and tests. There are lots of reasons we're not going to do it again, it's not something worth rehashing over and over again. This is fundamentally what you're doing if you decide to remove the subset of tempest tests used by defcore from the main repo and move them to something else. (it's just the opposite direction from the original tempest-lib split) All you're doing is making more work and a ton of synchronization headache for both the maintainers of tempest and its end users. That's something which is always ignored during these discussions, Tempest is a project with a defined scope (which includes the test suite itself, the plugin interface, and the library) and contract with its users and as the maintainers of tempest we can't just break this. Splitting out a big chunk of functionality from that into a separate project either significantly increases the burden on the maintainers, removes expected functionality from users, or both.

Also, option 1 was never ruled out, and there is no reason it couldn't work. It's just that no one has ever proposed a test to tempest for defcore outside the current set of projects it's testing. It's something the tempest team agreed to when 20160504 was proposed originally and that really hasn't changed. I don't think having add-on programs' tests live in the tempest tree will change the organizational structure of the interop program though, they'll still be optional add-ons and not tested by default. Which is why I prefer 2 to 1 because it matches the model.

As for tooling changes on the interop side there really aren't any that need to be made for any of these 3. There are no meaningful technical differences between 1, 2, and 3. This is all a social and organization question. The only difference is the selection arguments to use for the test runner (which is something refstack invokes/generates using the interop guideline json files) and potentially pip installing a plugin. These are all fairly straightforward to handle. Especially because we will always have to track which sets of tests go with which programs. Which is already something tracked in the interop repo."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2017-11-20 19:53:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I talked with Mark V about this, and he cleared up a few misconceptions I had about what amounts to the "production process" with regard to the refstack tests. The general process is that interop surveys existing tests (wherever they may lie) to find ones that are appropriate.

Thus the concerns that Matthew presents about needing to move some tests around are valid. However, I think the value of the difference in perception is much higher than he asserts.

I'll have to think about this more overnight but: Mark's input has made me less concerned about the issues with Option 2  (running the tests is from a list, that list knows how to find things from lots of places), but I still think _long term_ there is a great deal of value to Option 3 in terms of visibility and sociability for humans.'}, {'account_id': 6754, 'date': '2017-11-20 20:54:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

RefStack and the schema we use for interop guidelines were generally built with the idea in mind that it was entirely possible that all the tests we might want to use may not live in the same place (if you look at the current guideline, for example, you'll notice a "test-repositories" entity).  We've never actually included any tests that weren't in Tempest proper due partly to discussions with the TC a few years ago that lead to the 2016-05-04 resolution mentioned here.  That said, AFAIK the ability to handle multiple repos has never been removed, nor would we likely do so intentionally--especially with the advent of extension programs and vertical programs that didn't exist when the original TC resolution was crafted in 2016.


Since then we've had many discussions with teams that are interested in having their projects make their way into an interop program of some sort (the existing OpenStack Powered programs or more recently the add-on/vertical programs).  This has been a bit of a pain point as there's been reluctance for some projects that have plug-in tests hosted in another repo to move them into the Tempest tree.  The test itself wouldn't necessarily change much, but the sore point was that project teams would have to track the test and the code that implements the feature being tested in different repos with different core teams, and potentially even get into a situation where they have some tests (used for Interop guidelines) in one place and others (not used for Interop guidelines) in another.  


I'll also just confirm what cdent noted: the Interop WG generally doesn't do a lot of test creation itself.  The mantra has generally been that the projects who wrote the capability itself are probably in the best position to create a test that defines the capability as "working correctly" and we should just pull from that.  That's not to say it never happens...we do occasionally find gaps where there simply isn't a test [1], or we work on refactoring existing tests [2] so they better meet our criteria [3]; it's just not our primary MO.


Generally I'm fine with Option 2, but with a nit: I think "should be kept externally to the main Tempest repo" is perhaps a bit strong.  If there are existing tests in the tempest tree today that meet the criteria we need, I see no particular need to force projects to move them somewhere else.  That feels like we're making work for not much gain on the play.  It would be totally understandable if the project had some in-Tempest-tree and some in-project-tree and wanted to consolidate them into one location, but that's a call I think they can make on their own (and my guy feeling is that probably isn't the case for most anyway?  E.g. they're probably mostly all in one or the other place?).


There is an argument to be made that keeping all the tests in one place (ala option 3) would make things more consumable to human beings that want to test their clouds.  That said, at the risk of offering anecdotal evidence here it seems to me that most of the questions we get from people trying to run the tests are from vendors trying to certify a project, not from people trying to verify that a cloud they've built or are considering using actually does pass the tests that the Powered logo says it did.  Those vendors are generally reasonably comfortable dealing with multiple repos anyway (since they're shipping products built from multiple repos), so I'm not sure this saves too much from a humans-trying-to-wrap-their-heads-around-things perspective.  Those less comfortable working with multiple repos could probably be assisted with documentation or a bit of scripting on the RefStack side to make setup easier.  As noted previously, the guideline itself does list all the tests and the repo(s) in which they're located so we already have some record keeping done.  


Another concern is helping developers on the projects keep track of what tests are used in the Guidelines so they can treat them with care accordingly.  They could of course look at the Guideline doc, but that's probably not something one does as a matter of routine and habits are hard to change.  I think Chris Hoge had a proposal to use decorators in the tests a while back but it didn't get consensus.  If helping project teams track what tests are used for interop programs is a primary reason that folks are shying away from things like Option 2, perhaps it's a good time for a fresh look at how best to solve that problem.


[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/311747/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/335558/
[3] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/interop/tree/working_materials/interop_test_spec.rst'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2017-11-20 22:52:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks for the detailed response, Mark.

My position on this originally had more to do with the review and stability of the tests used for interop certification than it did with the test authors.

If we want interop tests to be stable, and there are review criteria that apply to those tests that do not apply to the general body of functional and integration tests, the first question to ask is what configuration makes it easiest to ensure we maintain the necessary stability and apply the appropriate review rules. We've spent a lot of time over the past few years talking about the merits of centralizing or decentralizing different types of work. I've come to believe that the best approach is to put the work near the people willing and able to do it. In this case, I'm not sure we have a system in place to train all of the contributors who might potentially touch the test cases so they understand the stability requirements for interop certification. That tells me we cannot distribute the work even if project teams are willing, and that placing the tests in a central location remains the best approach.

One way to react to that is to say that as part of gaining the tc:approved-release tag and being a part of a trademark certification program is the project team learns those rules and is somehow themselves "certified" as understanding them. However, as we have seen, people on various project teams come and go over time. We don't want the inclusion of a given project to depend on individual contributors continuing to work on the project. We also can't predict when someone might leave a team, since it is not always of their choice. We do, however, have a team of people working directly on the interop process and artifacts. That team is well placed to understand and apply those review rules and, supplemented with the QA team, seem like the right people to give the work to (they're the ones who want it done, after all).

So, if we accept that we want to have the tests under a centralized review team, the next question is are there any obstacles to moving the tests? As Matt points out, the QA team has already agreed to host tests used for interop testing within tempest as part of the original discussion on this point. No problem there. The remaining objection seems to be that it will make things harder for the original project teams.

The interop group has always claimed to "trail" the mainline development and production use of features due to the criteria that a feature be adopted by users before we require it. Therefore, by the time the feature is a candidate for interop testing the application code and tests will have long been developed. It should be straightforward to replicate the test so it is run from its current location and from tempest. It's then possible to delete the test from the original location, if desired. That should just be two patches in most cases. So, I don't consider it that big of a burden for test authors to "move" tests into tempest when they are going to be used for an interop certification criteria.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2017-11-21 13:43:38.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from interop-test-location-in-tempest to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2017-11-21 14:12:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Matt: The initial patchset had only options 1 and 2 - but I was asked to talk about Option 3.

The main reason I am interested in Option 1/3 is for the same reasoning that the TC asked all InterOp testing be in the repo - consistency of reviews.

I think that the add on programs can really benefit from having the tests in a location where people who are familiar with the requirements for changing an InterOp test will be in a position to review the changes.

In the original resolution, ensuring higher quality of reviews was one of the reasons cited for centralising the tests. Do add on programs have a lower bar for review quality? 

The add on programs will be unlikely to have been part of the core tempest test suite before, and may not have had a huge amount of experience or developers updating / maintaining tempest tests, and could risk causing issues to the trademark programs by changing things without knowing the full impact.

We also have the risk of tempest breaking the plugins, which has happened before.

I understand Option 3 is unpopular, but I have yet to hear what the actual technical issues with it are - does tempest/lib not have enough for the tests that are currently in tempest? 

@Mark: For the review consistency, and ensuring that a tempest change does not break a plugin and stop it from completing a RefStack test run I think we should reconsider, and keep Option 1, or go for Option 3, but not have Option 2. I know when anyone has asked Designate Option 1 has always been our prefered solution. The main reason we never proposed tests for the tempest repo was the uncertainty around where they should go.

@Doug: I think you are right - after the initial changes to add the boilerplate things (clients, service config etc) to tempest, moving individual tests is not a big deal.'}, {'account_id': 1921, 'date': '2017-11-21 16:22:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The reason we have a plugin mechanism in Tempest (and most QA projects) is because centralising does not scale from a review point of view with the QA team.

Many of the folks working on Tempest have a trained eye to catch changes that may open the way to interoperability issues; however that is just one aspect of the review. In that sense neither option 1 nor 3 help having high quality reviews.

Option 2 is probably the least work to implement and it seems like a good extension of what we have today.'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2017-11-21 17:15:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Then why do we require that non add ons trademark programs be centrally located? The previous resolution highights that centralising them helps improve the review quality - is that no longer true?

Also - ease for end users was highlighted as a reason to have them centralised ... is this no longer true as well?

> Centralizing the tests also makes it easier for anyone running the validation tool against their cloud or cloud distribution to use the tests. 1 - https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20160504-defcore-test-location.html'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2017-11-28 11:14:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I don't have strong feelings either way. It's a clear trade-off between basic review consistency across a trademark program (achieved via centralization) and increased review bandwidth (achieved via decentralization).

In an ideal world, tests would be maintained in separate repositories close to developers, with an extra vote from an interop-minded review group being necessary to change a test that happens to be used in a trademark program.

All options on the table are various ways to approximate this."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2017-11-28 11:17:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

That's certainly one way of looking at things, but another is that _if_ there is such a thing as a special interop test that needs to be in a trademark program and _if_ it might need review by people invested in that program why shouldn't those tests be 100% in the purview of those invested people even if it means some duplication of tests?

I'm not certain that that's how things should be, but it's not clear that that's not how things shoud be, either."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2017-11-28 13:29:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

My point is, it sounds like people would like the maintenance of tests to be distributed across all teams, but extra scrutiny / consistency placed on tests that happen to be used in interop/trademark programs. If modifying such tests would require a separate +1 vote from a specific interop-minded group to pass the gate, you could potentially get the best of both worlds.
