Following on from a discussion in #openstack-tc, it appears that Tempest is a victim of it's own success as a generically useful, pluggable test runner. As such it's being used for multiple different purposes:

  <cdent> the fact that we’ve got this same name for thing that does interop testing, cloud verification, and integration tests is chaos

I personally prefer option #3 - a centralised plugin repo for the interop tests. This is because interop tests potentially have a different life-cycle to other kinds of tests that might be run by tempest, and therefore it makes sense to keep them separately. This would also allow the QA core team to review patches to the tests, which is something they've said is important in the past.

I'd also be OK with #2 if it applied to _all_ of the trademark tests, including the core tests. I do think we'd want projects to maintain a repo specifically for interop tests (e.g. foo-tempest-interop) rather than lumping them in with other kinds of tests.

I'd also be OK with a combination of #3 & #2 - where core interop tests live in one plugin and add-on/vertical stuff live in separate foo-tempest-interop plugins. Add-on programs really are add-ons as far as the trademark program goes, and it's perfectly reasonable to keep them as separate plugins if there's some advantage to doing so. There'd be some cost involved when an add-on program becomes part of core, but fairly minimal considering the rarity of such an event (hasn't happened yet).

None of those, unfortunately, are going to satisfy Matt's criterion that tempest-lib and the interop tests must live in the same repo.

What I'm not a fan of is continuing to equate tempest the test runner with Tempest the set of tests used by defcore. That's confusing and leads to difficulties like the ones that prompted https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/queens/split-tempest-plugins.html#split-tempest-plugins-into-separate-repos-projects for projects that are using tempest plugins for purely CI testing purposes (which I would guess is *all* of them to some extent).

I'm not sure what a good compromise here might be. Maybe move the most tightly-coupled parts of tempest-lib into the interop plugin and specifically exclude them from the tempest-the-testrunner API?"}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2017-11-29 22:42:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Zane except tempest isn't a test runner. It does packages a CLI which includes a run command to simplify the end user experience outside of the usptream CI and handle some tempest specific logic. (like managing configuration and credential files for multiple clouds) But that just calls out to a test runner (currently testr, soon to be stestr) for running the tests. We just use it in the default CI jobs to self test the tempest CLI, but there isn't any requirement to use it and when I run tempest locally I don't normally use it.

Tempest is a test suite. There is a plugin interface to seamlessly add an external test suite as part of a run of the tempest suite. (and optionally share config options between them in a standard way) This is done using standard mechanisms in upstream python's unittest lib so it's test runner agnostic. You should totally be able to run tempest with plugins using py.test or any other runner. (it's never been tested though so you might hit bugs) Talking about decoupling the test suite from the plugin interface (which is what I assume you mean by test runner) just doesn't make any sense because plugins are literally about adding extra testing into the tempest test suite. What you're really talking about is splitting the test suite into multiple repos to change a perception held by a few people. But, as I said earlier, doing that has real harms for the maintainers and potentially the users of tempest. We've also tried splitting the repo in the past and had to undo that because of the headaches it not only caused the tempest team, but the wider openstack project. I'm a hard -2 on any proposed change to tempest trying to do this.

Another thing that's also worth pointing out here is in Chris's comment Zane quotes from IRC is implying all 3 are distinct tests. Which in reality is not the case, they're all different applications for the same tests. Part of the reason tempest is used for all 3 functions is because in a bunch of cases (the vast majority actually) when you write a black box test to work against a running cloud all 3 of those functions (and probably several others) are served by the same test. Take for example a volume attach test: https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/master/tempest/api/compute/volumes/test_attach_volume.py#L61-L111 That's an integration test that involves interactions with multiple services, it is incredibly useful for verifying your cloud works, and is used to test interop. (https://github.com/openstack/interop/blob/master/2017.09.json#L1005 ) It doesn't make any sense to have 3 versions of that test for different testing use cases. While not every test can fit every role, (which is part of why the interopWG doesn't use every tempest test) arbitrarily splitting things based on perceived classifications of tests doesn't really serve anyone. Especially when you realize these definitions are all completely subjective. Like what I see as an integration test could be different from cdent's view which differs from hogepodge's. We've also gone done that test classification bikeshed many times in tempest. (which is why the names of the types of testing in the repo have changed a couple times in the history of the project) As I said earlier Tempest has a defined scope on the kind of testing it does and those tests can have many different applications.

Also an aside, if you're not running any of the other tempest tests in your CI jobs then there is no reason to use tempest plugins. Unless you want to enable external users to integrate running those tests as part of a larger test run. Which is often the reason projects use plugins. If you don't think anyone will do that just don't use the plugin interface there is no requirement for CI testing to use tempest's plugin mechanism at all. The goal is literally about fixing packaging and ecosystem harms caused by bundling the setuptools entrypoint used for the plugin interface in a python project (which with pbr means a git repo) that's primary purpose isn't to be a plugin. It also definitely effects projects using plugins from a "purely CI" purpose (which I don't feel is actually a thing, because almost every plugin in openstack/ I've seen used downstream at some point, that's kind of the point of plugins). A big part of the motivation for pushing that goal was project's breaking each other's CI jobs. A very common scenario before the goal was:

 - Project X would land a new plugin entrypoint or added a requirement to an existing plugin. 
 - The new plugin was broken and failed on import (normally because it landed before CI was setup) or the new plugin only
   requirement was never installed outside of Project X's gate jobs
 - Project Y installed project X in it's gate jobs.
 - Project Y's CI job starts failing 100% of the time with an import error during the initial test discovery scan.

That pattern was a very common occurrence and was something I was helping people debug at least weekly before we started pushing the community goal.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2017-12-01 19:43:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> @Zane except tempest isn't a test runner.

Yeah, my bad, I couldn't think of any good terminology for what I was trying to describe, so I borrowed a term from Python that has a different technical meaning.

What I mean is that there are lots of things that make a tempest an attractive way to run tests. Some of those are inside tempest (convenience stuff that nobody wants to have to copy and paste; shared config). Some are outside (everyone already knows how to run tempest from Zuul, so if you put your tests in a tempest plugin then you're done; tempest tests can be run by Rally). Another is the network effect: if you want to be able to pull in tests from multiple sources and run them all in a single batch then you need a standardised plugin system, and tempest is the only game in town.

> Talking about decoupling the test suite from the plugin interface (which is what I assume you mean by test runner)

Yes, I think this is what I mean.

> just doesn't make any sense because plugins are literally about adding extra testing into the tempest test suite.

Not sure I follow here. There's nothing unusual about having a plugin-only interface. It's certainly possible for the core suite to be empty and have all of the tests contributed by plugins. Clearly that's not how it has been conceived of to date and it may be a bad idea because of reasons, but is it really nonsensical by definition?

> What you're really talking about is splitting the test suite into multiple repos to change a perception held by a few people.

So assuming that we agree that those perceptions need to be changed, and given that you think that splitting the repo is a non-starter (and I totally respect that, as the representative of the people actually maintaining it, you must have the final say on that), what are some other ways we can change perceptions?

It occurs to me that it might help if we had a comprehensive taxonomy of all the different kinds of tests folks might want to run against clouds (this will involve talking to all of the projects, as there are likely a wide variety), and recommendations for how each should be handled. Off the top of my head, and in order from most stable (can be decoupled from the service being tested) to least stable (most coupled to the service being tested), we have at least:

1) Core trademark program interop
2) Add-on trademark program interop
3) 'Upstream' integration tests (you export tests to run in the gate of a service you depend upon to help ensure it doesn't break you)
4) Integration tests (you check that your service interacts as expected with another service from your perspective)
5) Configuration tests (an operator of a cloud checks that it's actually working. I'd include performance testing with Rally in this category)
6) Regression tests (you check that your service does what it should, independently of any interaction with another service)

Some tests will certainly be in multiple categories. I think it's reasonable to say that where this is the case we should treat it as a member of the most-stable category that it's in. Where categories commonly share tests it probably makes sense to keep those tests as close together as possible (e.g. using tags instead of separate repos).

Tempest started as 3 & 4 for the small set of projects that existed at the time, and 1 later piggy-backed on it. This review was initially a response to the fact that we don't have an answer for 2 yet. The IRC discussion referenced above and the thread that prompted it (http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-November/125001.html) is a response to the fact that we don't really have an answer for 6. In my corner of the world nobody except for the starter-kit:compute projects is doing 3, and perhaps separating it clearly from 4/6 would encourage more of it. No tests exist solely in level 5 but it might drag some out of level 6.

The disposition of a test is a combination of several factors:

* Part of the tempest suite (including plugins) or completely standalone
* In the tempest tree or in a separate plugin repo or in the project repo
* Branchless or with stable branches
* Tagging e.g. with decorators

Now seems like a good time to try to lock down and document a standard way of combining these tools to get tests in the right place for each of the categories above. I remember we sort-of asked about this (in a much less detailed way) around the time that Heat first started doing in-tree functional tests (previously we only had a small handful of Tempest tests) and the response from the QA team was basically that this was uncharted territory and that we should try something and we'd all learn as we go - which was an excellent response at the time. It seems like we've learned a bunch since then. We learned that the tempest-plugin + in-project-repo combination is an antipattern (at least if the plugin is installed automatically), for example. So it seems like the time could be ripe to collect these lessons into concrete recommendations of what *to* do, not just what not to do. WDYT?

> Also an aside, if you're not running any of the other tempest tests in your CI jobs then there is no reason to use tempest plugins. Unless you want to enable external users to integrate running those tests as part of a larger test run. Which is often the reason projects use plugins.

Wearing my downstream hat for a second, I do value the ability to run all of the tests (including category 6) via a Tempest plugin. That's secondary to upstream considerations though - i.e. I would rather work around tests not being in a plugin downstream than to be breaking the gate with an in-tree plugin upstream."}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2017-12-01 23:05:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> > @Zane except tempest isn't a test runner.
 > 
 > Yeah, my bad, I couldn't think of any good terminology for what I
 > was trying to describe, so I borrowed a term from Python that has a
 > different technical meaning.
 > 
 > What I mean is that there are lots of things that make a tempest an
 > attractive way to run tests. Some of those are inside tempest
 > (convenience stuff that nobody wants to have to copy and paste;
 > shared config).

This use case is why we have the library interface for tempest. (https://docs.openstack.org/tempest/latest/library.html ) This is independent from the plugin interface and can be used by anything. I even have some personal projects that use the clients from tempest lib directly (using https://github.com/mtreinish/mesocyclone ) While config isn't technically part of this we provide stability and backwards compat guarantees on it, we just don't support it outside of the plugin interface. This is mostly because getting the ordering right for oslo.config when running under a test runner where you don't have control of import or execution is very tricky. We didn't want to be in the game of owning that for everyone's independent test suites. (it took a long time to get it right in tempest) But, there is nothing stopping people from doing reusing tempest.config outside of a plugin.

 > Some are outside (everyone already knows how to run
 > tempest from Zuul, so if you put your tests in a tempest plugin
 > then you're done; tempest tests can be run by Rally). Another is
 > the network effect: if you want to be able to pull in tests from
 > multiple sources and run them all in a single batch then you need a
 > standardised plugin system, and tempest is the only game in town.

Well except for unittest itself. Tempest isn't really doing anything special here, it's just leveraging the tools already available in unittest. (and sprinkling stevedore on top)

 > 
 > > Talking about decoupling the test suite from the plugin interface
 > (which is what I assume you mean by test runner)
 > 
 > Yes, I think this is what I mean.
 > 
 > > just doesn't make any sense because plugins are literally about
 > adding extra testing into the tempest test suite.
 > 
 > Not sure I follow here. There's nothing unusual about having a
 > plugin-only interface. It's certainly possible for the core suite
 > to be empty and have all of the tests contributed by plugins.
 > Clearly that's not how it has been conceived of to date and it may
 > be a bad idea because of reasons, but is it really nonsensical by
 > definition?

What I meant is by just having a standalone plugin interface all it would just be python unittest at that point. All the tempest plugin interface is just a combination of stevedore and unittest discovery which is why any external python test suite that works with discovery can be a plugin. The point of having the plugin interface being coupled with the test suite is because you want the plugins discovered at the same time by the test runner when you tell it to run discovery on the tempest suite. If you were to decouple that you're not really a plugin anymore and just running multiple test suites leveraging python's unittest api.

I mean sure, technically there is nothing stopping you from splitting the repo up and have the stevedore + unittest glue (which by the way is like 50 lines: https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/master/tempest/test_discover/plugins.py#L175-L225 and https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/master/tempest/test_discover/test_discover.py#L46-L54 ) and then have the tempest in the requirements list (and it exposes the entrypoint) for the new project. But IMHO that doesn't change or solve anything except we have a new project with only like 50 lines of code. But if you talk about decoupling that from the actual tests then there is no need for a plugin interface because then you just have multiple test suites and your test runner can probably handle that. (or you can leverage bits in unittest to handle that) There really isn't a role for "plugins" anymore, you'd just have a bunch of related test suites that potentially re-use the same lib code and maybe share config. This, by the way, is the first model we attempted here and no one was happy with it. That's why tempest-lib started first because our idea was we'd provide a stable external interface for some of the tempest previously internal tempest helpers and stuff and then people could write tests with that. What people ended up asking for was a way to seamless integrate that into a run of the tempest suite which is why we added the plugin interface like a year later.

If the stevedore bit is the magic piece people want I created: https://github.com/mtreinish/stevetest to do this generically for all unittest suites. (it's 49 lines of code)

 > 
 > > What you're really talking about is splitting the test suite into
 > multiple repos to change a perception held by a few people.
 > 
 > So assuming that we agree that those perceptions need to be
 > changed, and given that you think that splitting the repo is a
 > non-starter (and I totally respect that, as the representative of
 > the people actually maintaining it, you must have the final say on
 > that), what are some other ways we can change perceptions?
 > 
 > It occurs to me that it might help if we had a comprehensive
 > taxonomy of all the different kinds of tests folks might want to
 > run against clouds (this will involve talking to all of the
 > projects, as there are likely a wide variety), and recommendations
 > for how each should be handled. Off the top of my head, and in
 > order from most stable (can be decoupled from the service being
 > tested) to least stable (most coupled to the service being tested),
 > we have at least:
 > 
 > 1) Core trademark program interop
 > 2) Add-on trademark program interop
 > 3) 'Upstream' integration tests (you export tests to run in the
 > gate of a service you depend upon to help ensure it doesn't break
 > you)
 > 4) Integration tests (you check that your service interacts as
 > expected with another service from your perspective)

I'm not sure I understand this distinction here. Is 3 just co-gating, so having the same jobs run between projects? While 4 is just 3 without co-gating?

 > 5) Configuration tests (an operator of a cloud checks that it's
 > actually working. I'd include performance testing with Rally in
 > this category)

To a certain extent I would view this as an application of 1-4 with maybe some extra things. Like when I do a cloud deployment I run tempest against it to verify the functionality works. But, basically any tests that can work against any deployment would fit into this category, or am I missing something?

 > 6) Regression tests (you check that your service does what it
 > should, independently of any interaction with another service)
 > 
 > Some tests will certainly be in multiple categories. I think it's
 > reasonable to say that where this is the case we should treat it as
 > a member of the most-stable category that it's in. Where categories
 > commonly share tests it probably makes sense to keep those tests as
 > close together as possible (e.g. using tags instead of separate
 > repos).

I think the only thing here is that these definitions aren't as clear cut as they might first seem. A lot of this just depends on how you choose to run something, or why you're running a test. It's not necessarily something you can just look at and say "that's an integration test". The subjective nature of this is something we struggle with on tempest reviews all the time when reviewing incoming tests. I think having a doc with a shared lexicon is useful, just to frame discussion, but it won't be an answer for everything. 

 > 
 > Tempest started as 3 & 4 for the small set of projects that existed
 > at the time, and 1 later piggy-backed on it. This review was
 > initially a response to the fact that we don't have an answer for 2
 > yet. The IRC discussion referenced above and the thread that
 > prompted it (http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-November/125001.html)
 > is a response to the fact that we don't really have an answer for
 > 6.

Tempest also has a role as #5 back in 2013 when we made the decision to support running on any cloud explicitly. (instead of just the implicit assumption it would) This is why it works for #1. I also know of a lot of downstream useage to test out deployments, including some who wrote automation (like a couple of nagios plugins I've seen) to use it for alarming. 

I would say #6 is something that does exist, there just is no unified model for doing this. (and the standards for this kind of testing varies drastically between projects) But, a bunch of projects each have there own answer for this. Which I think is actually how it should be, because if it's really isolated to a single project then the needs will be unique. In the openstack world we've been traditionally calling this functional tests. For example, I feel like the nova functional test suite https://github.com/openstack/nova/tree/master/nova/tests/functional is a good example of this. (there is even a dedicated set of regression tests for past bugs: https://github.com/openstack/nova/tree/master/nova/tests/functional/regressions :) )

 > In my corner of the world nobody except for the
 > starter-kit:compute projects is doing 3, and perhaps separating it
 > clearly from 4/6 would encourage more of it. No tests exist solely
 > in level 5 but it might drag some out of level 6.
 > 
 > The disposition of a test is a combination of several factors:
 > 
 > * Part of the tempest suite (including plugins) or completely
 > standalone
 > * In the tempest tree or in a separate plugin repo or in the
 > project repo
 > * Branchless or with stable branches
 > * Tagging e.g. with decorators
 > 
 > Now seems like a good time to try to lock down and document a
 > standard way of combining these tools to get tests in the right
 > place for each of the categories above. I remember we sort-of asked
 > about this (in a much less detailed way) around the time that Heat
 > first started doing in-tree functional tests (previously we only
 > had a small handful of Tempest tests) and the response from the QA
 > team was basically that this was uncharted territory and that we
 > should try something and we'd all learn as we go - which was an
 > excellent response at the time. It seems like we've learned a bunch
 > since then. We learned that the tempest-plugin + in-project-repo
 > combination is an antipattern (at least if the plugin is installed
 > automatically), for example. So it seems like the time could be
 > ripe to collect these lessons into concrete recommendations of what
 > *to* do, not just what not to do. WDYT?

Sure writing docs and creating a high level guide to types of testing out there and the basic theory behind how the pieces fit together is a good idea. It's something I know that I've talked to several people in the past about (not just the discussion with heat from a while ago you referenced). I also think a lot of this might already exist sprinkled inside the tempest docs and a bunch of other places, but having a unified doc makes sense. I'm not sure I have the bandwidth to drive that effort right now though. I also feel it would be an effort a bit outside the scope of this review. :) Related sure, but we still need to answer the question here about interop tests independently of that future work.

 > 
 > > Also an aside, if you're not running any of the other tempest
 > tests in your CI jobs then there is no reason to use tempest
 > plugins. Unless you want to enable external users to integrate
 > running those tests as part of a larger test run. Which is often
 > the reason projects use plugins.
 > 
 > Wearing my downstream hat for a second, I do value the ability to
 > run all of the tests (including category 6) via a Tempest plugin.
 > That's secondary to upstream considerations though - i.e. I would
 > rather work around tests not being in a plugin downstream than to
 > be breaking the gate with an in-tree plugin upstream.

I think a fine answer for a project team to come up with as a response to the community goal is to just remove the entrypoint and not have testing via the plugins. What we've found though is that existing plugins have active users who are depending on it downstream. For example, we tried to remove the trove plugin as a response to the goal because besides being in-tree it also had no real value (it literally only tested the trove flavors proxy api to nova) and was completely unmaintained. When we landed that patch people came with torches and pitchforks because they were depending on it for their testing. So we had to add it back.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2017-12-04 14:47:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> I think the only thing here is that these definitions aren't as
 > clear cut as they might first seem. A lot of this just depends on
 > how you choose to run something, or why you're running a test. It's
 > not necessarily something you can just look at and say "that's an
 > integration test". The subjective nature of this is something we
 > struggle with on tempest reviews all the time when reviewing
 > incoming tests. I think having a doc with a shared lexicon is
 > useful, just to frame discussion, but it won't be an answer for
 > everything.

A common tool when there is ambiguity of meaning and where the differences are meaningful and important but hard to discern is to put things in different boxes. It's certainly much easier to grasp something's meaning when it is in a box labelled after that meaning (such as interop test) than when it is in a box of "miscellaneous tests" and has one of several local labels (such as a directory or decorator).'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2017-12-04 16:12:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> > I think the only thing here is that these definitions aren't as
 > > clear cut as they might first seem. A lot of this just depends on
 > > how you choose to run something, or why you're running a test.
 > It's
 > > not necessarily something you can just look at and say "that's an
 > > integration test". The subjective nature of this is something we
 > > struggle with on tempest reviews all the time when reviewing
 > > incoming tests. I think having a doc with a shared lexicon is
 > > useful, just to frame discussion, but it won't be an answer for
 > > everything.
 > 
 > A common tool when there is ambiguity of meaning and where the
 > differences are meaningful and important but hard to discern is to
 > put things in different boxes. It's certainly much easier to grasp
 > something's meaning when it is in a box labelled after that meaning
 > (such as interop test) than when it is in a box of "miscellaneous
 > tests" and has one of several local labels (such as a directory or
 > decorator).

Except for that to work you have to be able to look at a test and say that it fits the label. You actually can't do that here. (which was my whole point in the above quote) The "interop tests" are just a subset of tests selected every 6 months for the guidelines. There are some criteria, but they more describe what can't be used instead of what an interop test is. What you'd end up doing is splitting things up arbitrarily based on a list that is mostly subjective and also changes every 6 months. This literally won't change anything except cause a bunch of churn moving things between repos as things change. It also just starts raising more questions of why doesn't my awesome new test go in interop repo X, instead of integration test repo Y, instead of config testing repo Z, instead of being an in tree functional test.

Here's another metaphor, at home I have a hardware organizer that's got a lot of different types of screws. Including one box for #6 x 1-1/4 in. course thread drywall screws. That's a defined thing that I can identify and categorize fairly easily without any question that what I put in the box is a #6 x 1-1/4in course thread drywall screw. But, being in that box doesn't mean I can only use those to attach drywall to a stud. I often use them on projects with MDF (despite the name saying drywall). But, I don't make a second box that says #6 - 1-1/4 in. course thread drywall screws that are used for MDF. If I did do that when cleaning up leftover screws how do I decide which box the #6 - 1-1/4 in. course thread drywall screws go into?

Tempest has a defined scope on what kind of testing it does. and a mostly objective criteria for deciding if something is in scope for the project. (there is a still a certain degree of subjectivity to it, because code is not the same thing as screws) You personally might view it as too broad, but that's not something that can be addressed with a governance review. (it's a per project decision to discuss in the context of tempest) The different applications of how that testing is used isn't something tempest really cares about, which is why there aren't decorators or directories on the different potential applications of the testing. (only on different defined aspects of what a test does, like what services does it talk to) The problem with your box for interop testing is there isn't anyway to actually distinguish it from any other test, except for the fact it's being used by a consumer of tempest for that particular application.

The model that exists today with a defined the list of what's being used for the interop and trademark program is quite frankly a much better fit for how things actually work. When you consider that nothing is actually written as an "interop test" but instead they're all written as blackbox REST API driven tests designed to work against any cloud. Then the interop WG chooses a subset of those to use for the program. If you want to know which tests are used for interop program, you just check the list. That's why if you only care about running tests for interop you use refstack which just runs the tempest tests with a selection filter for only the tests from the list. (ignoring the results uploading part of refstack)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2017-12-04 16:42:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Matt, we are essentially agreeing with one another on the state of affairs but reaching a different conclusion. If I understand you correctly, you are saying, in part, "existing tests are used in multiple ways and as a result managing them in a way that tries to strictly constrain them will result in churn, confusion and extra work."

I'm suggesting that we should consider (at least as a mental exercise to be _explicitly_ clear that it is not good, rather than taking it on faith) of changing the reality you describe in "When you consider that nothing is actually written as an 'interop test' but instead they're all written as blackbox REST API driven tests designed to work against any cloud." or "why doesn't my awesome new test go in interop repo X, instead of integration test repo Y, instead of config testing repo Z, instead of being an in tree functional test" to instead be:

Test are written, used, and managed for specific purposes by the people who want tests for those purposes and maintained in repos managed by those people. Yes, this could mean some duplication of tests but I don't really see this as a problem because of the contextual help that the different style of grouping would allow.

The end game here is people being engaged with and responsible for the tests that matter to them in a visible and decodable fashion that also happens minimize ways in which perceptions of unfairness can happen.

You'll note that I've not voted on this since my early -1 (when it was still two options). I'm not going to fight to the death over this and will happily abide by whatever consensus we reach but thus far I've not seen anything compelling to sway my opinion all that much other than "how things actually work". Until we have more people participating in the conversation I suspect I won't, I hope they come along soon.

How things work _now_ should only rarely be a strict controlling factor for how things should work later. This is why I think debating this stuff is something "that can be addressed with a governance review". For right or wrong (sometimes often very wrong), this is the forum within which we debate.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2017-12-05 16:35:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

>> 3) 'Upstream' integration tests (you export tests to run in the
>> gate of a service you depend upon to help ensure it doesn't break
>> you)
>> 4) Integration tests (you check that your service interacts as
>> expected with another service from your perspective)
>
> I'm not sure I understand this distinction here. Is 3 just co-gating, so having the same jobs run between projects? While 4 is just 3 without co-gating?

Yeah, I think that's a better summary of the difference.

>> 5) Configuration tests (an operator of a cloud checks that it's
>> actually working. I'd include performance testing with Rally in
>> this category)
>
> To a certain extent I would view this as an application of 1-4 with maybe some extra things. Like when I do a cloud deployment I run tempest against it to verify the functionality works. But, basically any tests that can work against any deployment would fit into this category, or am I missing something?

The idea was that there are some tests that might otherwise fall into category 6 (i.e. they aren't testing integration with anything else per se) and therefore not get exported outside of the project tree, that nevertheless are useful for someone checking that their cloud is configured correctly and thus need to live somewhere closer to the tests for category 3/4 so that they're available externally. I'd expect that most category 5 tests would already be classified in a higher category though. (I'm also not 100% convinced I got the order right. Maybe 4 & 5 should be switched?)

> If the stevedore bit is the magic piece people want I created: https://github.com/mtreinish/stevetest to do this generically for all unittest suites. (it's 49 lines of code)

This is actually pretty interesting to me. Even more so if we could make the test suite name configurable - i.e. instead of always using stevetest.test_plugins as the endpoint it could be something like stevetest.<name of zuul job>, or maybe less granularly stevetest.<name of project>_test_plugins (we'd probably want to use NamedExtensionManager as well so we could whitelist the plugins allowed in the job - if for no other reason then to enable quick recovery if the gate is wedged). Tempest would be one of many endpoints you could contribute plugins to, and of course you could make the same tests available to multiple endpoints for co-gating purposes without necessarily involving the starter-kit:compute test suite at all. I'd be interested to hear what other folks think about it."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2017-12-09 17:54:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I think I've caught up on everything here, though since the amount of prose in the comments far dwarfs the amount in the actual proposal, I'm still processing some of it.

I think some of this points to the fact that there is confusion in general about what tempest is, and what belongs where means it is not obvious from just looking at things what it's intent and purpose is.

I think what would make sense, and maybe help clear up some of the confusion, would be going with option 2. At least my interpreted understanding of option 2.

(I'm just going to call it defcore for the sake of simplicity even though I know that is no longer the name)

We define defcore so there is a known set of functionality that we can expect from any OpenStack cloud. Since tempest is used to validate a deployment, it makes sense to me that what is in openstack/tempest proper should just be those things that are part of defcore. This serves a few purposes. It Makes it clear what is expected to be there. It gives assurance that whatever is tested by that is an acceptable "OpenStack powered" cloud. And it makes it clear to those configuring things if they are setting up everything that should be expected in a deployment.

There are additional types of clouds we want to support with a different set of functional requirements. As someone that would want to validate if a given cloud supports one of these other scenarios, it would make sense to me to have to add the "OpenStack NFV" validation plugin or the "OpenStack Edge" plugin and get an additive set of tests for core expected functionality for those types of environments.

Then there is the set of functionality that isn't common and isn't part of an official expected functionality but that a deployer may want to configure for their specific use cases. These are the things that I see each project having in-tree (or now in-out-of-tree) to be able to have more comprehensive test coverage of those things that may or may not be enabled.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-01-07 20:09:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Coming to this late, but after mulling on the commentary I support whatever consensus the QA and Interop teams manage to reach. They're in the best position to judge the impact to the ecosystem and also those at risk of suffering the greatest inconveniences from any bad decision here. It probably mostly comes down to getting some clear documentation explaining the status quo and why it's not an arbitrary pronouncement of which projects are part of the "in crowd" vs second-class participants.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-01-11 15:04:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Coming to this late, but after mulling on the commentary I support
 > whatever consensus the QA and Interop teams manage to reach.
 > They're in the best position to judge the impact to the ecosystem
 > and also those at risk of suffering the greatest inconveniences
 > from any bad decision here. It probably mostly comes down to
 > getting some clear documentation explaining the status quo and why
 > it's not an arbitrary pronouncement of which projects are part of
 > the "in crowd" vs second-class participants.

The issue I have with the current situation is exactly that sense of "unfair" treatment of different projects. That's a social problem, and it sounds like we have some technical issues with resolving it but it also seems to me that not everyone recognizes that the problem exists in the first place and we're not going to find a technical solution until we come to agreement on that. So let's stop worrying about plugin tools and co-gating and address the underlying social problem first.

The original intent behind placing the interop tests within the tempest repository was to ensure that all of the tests were in one place and under the purview of a team that would understand the extra requirements. At the time, the QA team said they would accept tests for new projects as they were added to the interop program. Has that position changed? If so, why?

If the position has not changed, why are we talking about this?'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-01-11 17:28:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> If the position has not changed, why are we talking about this?

What has changed is that there is now more than one interop program, which is a possibility that was not anticipated when the current policy was arrived at.

There's a lot of historical baggage embedded in the current system, and it causes a lot of confusion. TBH that's a bigger concern to me than the fairness angle."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-01-11 18:31:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

The Interop Working Group will be seeking approval of add-on programs for Heat and Designate at the February 2018 OpenStack Board Meeting, with an official trademark program launch by the OpenStack Foundation following in the first half of 2018. 

From the standpoint of technical implementation, we're requiring that advisory add-on projects have a Tempest plug-in, in part to conform with established community testing guidelines and in part to take advantage of refstack-client's ability to run tests from Tempest and Tempest plug-ins. In considering new programs, we need to start with existing tests, and project conformance with the TC DefCore resolution would require new test capabilities to be moved into the Tempest repository.

Official clarification on the preferred final location of add-on API tests from the TC and QA teams is appreciated. It's notable that for program implementation, the Interop WG is a board chartered and Foundation implemented group, but we strongly consider TC intentions in crafting program rules and policies. Guidance on this issue is valuable and will help us work with individual project teams and the QA team on continuing development of the interoperability and trademark programs.

http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/governance/tree/resolutions/20160504-defcore-test-location.rst"}, {'account_id': 8434, 'date': '2018-01-17 02:14:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I agree with Chris (and Matt for that matter).  Having worked on this since almost the beginning, it made sense the original, foundational project tests resided in the tempest directories, but the add-ons are that and some of the same reasoning behind the creation and roll-out of tempest plugins holds the same  power when discussing the trademark tests.  They are add-ons; important enough to require that they run in the tempest framework, but not central enough to require they are embedded in the tempest  repos. So, option 2 is fine.  The tests are created by the developers who design the code, but are run through QA's test framework, tempest.  A good compromise of employing the knowledge of the develeopers with the standards of the test team.  

I believe Option 2 provides both for QA flexibility and Interop robustness.  And, Refstack needs no extra development to accommodate the structure."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-01-19 04:13:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I believe we found a good compromise for the short-term issues following the discussion with the TC at the PTG today. (Thanks jroll for the suggestion.) The idea is that add-on programs will get their own tempest plugin repos (like e.g. tempest-orchestration-interop-plugin, tempest-dns-interop-plugin) that contain *only* the refstack tests and will be part of the QA program for the purposes of projects.yaml, but where the core teams from QA, the project being tested, and refstack will all have +2/-2 rights. Existing tests will be moved over from their current plugins as-is (including Gabbi tests). Co-gating will be organised to prevent breakage. This appears to be acceptable to each of the QA, Heat, Designate, and RefStack teams, and I believe helps satisfy Doug's concerns in that it's abundantly clear which code needs special care to avoid interop breakage, and QA will have the ability to review and -2 as necessary. Graham will update this review presently with the details."}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-03-05 22:51:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-03-05 23:00:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I do like the idea of having all tests in one well known and defined location (or locations). I do wonder about then having duplication or the need to move tests around from a project's general tempest plugin to an official trademark program location.

One idea (and sorry to throw out yet another one), I wonder if we can introduce a decorator that can be used in project's tempest plugin so that all of the tests can be kept in one location. But then trademark review and test runs can be set up to only pull out and run those tests that are decorated with this. Something along the lines of:

@trademark_program('nfv-vertical')
def test_stuff(self):
   pass

This could then make it easier for tests that overlap between add-on programs to be identified and included in those validation test runs.

Just a thought."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-03-07 10:10:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

This is mostly good. I have some quibbles (noted within) about repo ownership. I think it is important that all the stakeholders have skin in the game.

I think early comments about test duplication are not really all that important. I think it is more important that the trademark/interop tests exist as independent and fairly static things. We should not be using them for other purposes and they should change infrequently. Being able to identify them as a separate thing helps that.

Finally, I would prefer that we make it explicit in here that tests which are not exclusively managed by QA can use what tooling they like (as long as they present tests that tempest can track). Otherwise, we are not capturing the problem experience by heat last Friday with regard to using gabbi for their (already accepted by the board) tests.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-03-07 13:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

It's unfortunate, as Thierry pointed out, that we weren't able to bring all of the affected parties into the room at the same time last week to discuss the issues with the trademark program and testing.

This proposal, while trying to capture the output of the several separate meetings we did have, feels overly detailed for a governance resolution for which the effect is basically to say we're going to drop the old requirement that interop tests live in a single repo with a review team that understands the review policies related to the trademark program.

If we are going to allow project teams to manage tests wherever they want and the interop team is OK with that (as they seem to be, since that’s what has happened regardless of the guidance given previously), then let's just say that the interop team is free to accept whatever tests they want to use, with the understanding that the interop WG and the team that owns the repo share the responsibility for ensuring those tests remain suitable for trademark enforcement.

The interop WG should document any guidelines they want teams to follow in creating and maintaining the tests, including what tools they find acceptable, how the trademark enforcement tools will run the tests, etc. to define what "suitable for trademark enforcement" means. That documentation would take the place of the details we're trying to hash out here in this governance resolution, but they would be managed by the team that cares most directly about them and can maintain them more easily.

The TC will continue to manage the tc-approved-release tag as an indication of projects we consider “ready” to be considered for the trademark program(s), while staying out of the way of the interop WG's ability to manage the more detailed work of identifying capabilities and the tests that define them.

The QA team will no longer need to be concerned about their workload increasing as the trademark program expands, though they may be called upon to expand or otherwise enhance the public APIs provided by tempest.

And project teams can retain ownership of their test suites, with the caveat that breaking them may mean losing trademark status at the discretion of the interop WG.'}, {'account_id': 6754, 'date': '2018-03-07 14:43:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(4 comments)

> It's unfortunate, as Thierry pointed out, that we weren't able to bring all of the affected parties into the room at the same time last week to discuss the issues with the trademark program and testing.

Yeah, that has made this discussion very challenging. That said, this specific proposal was the outcome of a discussion following the TC session, based on a suggestion from jroll, between me and Rico, Graham, Andrea, and Mark, during which we agreed in principle on this approach. So all teams were represented, although obviously we weren't able to get input from everyone.

> Other issue with co-ownership is that If tests are not tempest like tests then, it is little difficult for QA team to control or input on tests.

I'm curious if you've ever looked at any gabbi tests?

http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/heat-tempest-plugin/tree/heat_tempest_plugin/tests/api/gabbits/templates.yaml

If anything it's a lot simpler.

> And if it is also owned by project then how it make sure to control that test is not modified intentionally by projects team.

Look, short of gating against a bunch of live clouds, nothing is prefect. But this seems pretty good, and a lot better than having stuff owned solely by project teams with no input from QA at all, which would be the opposite of a solution to your concern.

The constraints we're trying to solve for here are:

* Nobody wants the interop tests to break, ever.
* The QA team has very limited review bandwidth and doesn't want to take anything else on (although note that they have already agreed to take on responsibility for reviewing Heat and Designate interop tests).
* The QA team doesn't want to depend on Gabbi in Tempest.
* The Designate team wants input from the QA team, who are the experts on e.g. tempest clients, on their interop tests so they don't accidentally break anything.
* The Heat team wants to not be forced to rewrite their API tests for a third time, especially not now that the Gabbi tests have been approved by the board.
* The RefStack team wants us all to get our house in order and just pick an option so they can move ahead.

This proposal satisfies all of those constraints. If somebody has another proposal that also satisfies the constraints, great, I'd love to hear it. But none of the others presented so far do."}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2018-03-07 18:31:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-03-07 19:10:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

In an effort to provide a simplified version of this I've proposed I2e68c8e855e7c6c1e4f985f38a0a38de451407a3 which is not perfect by any stretch but maybe a bit more direct."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-03-07 23:11:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

> > Other issue with co-ownership is that If tests are not tempest
 > like tests then, it is little difficult for QA team to control or
 > input on tests.
 > 
 > I'm curious if you've ever looked at any gabbi tests?
Yes i did :) and it is not about what is simple or complex it is about what a particular team scope is. For Tempest team, it is difficult to have dependency on gabbi or other framework in future if any.

 > This proposal satisfies all of those constraints. If somebody has
 > another proposal that also satisfies the constraints, great, I'd
 > love to hear it. But none of the others presented so far do.
I agree on proposal as overall and it is completely perfect to me. Only comment i have and as dhellmann also mentioned ownership of those repo will stay on project side not QA.
QA team will be always be there to give their input. for example helping designate to standardize their tests and interfaces to avoid breaking them."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-03-08 01:50:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: -Code-Review

> For Tempest team, it is difficult to have dependency on gabbi or other framework in future if any.

Yeah, I understand you have that concern and that's largely the reason why we're attempting this compromise, so that Tempest doesn't gain a dependency on Gabbi."}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-03-22 19:40:18.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

I2e68c8e855e7c6c1e4f985f38a0a38de451407a3 clarified this patch and has majority support, so closing out this change.'}]

commit_message:
get rid of oslo.utils

we are using just several simple methods from oslo.utils which requires
a lot of other dependecies.

To make rally a lightweight framework, we need to abandon usage of such
things

Change-Id: I6e6170c7dabc97a089d030ee6b05fc07993e8c32

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-16 15:01:55.000000000', 'message': "Fix typo and misleading task name for nova-consoleauth

The services for console are installed in the 'Install nova
console/metadata services' task, however, the scheduler
install task misleadingly is named to mention that it installs
consoleauth and tries to run on the nova_consoleauth group
which does not exist.

Change-Id: If7c00cbfe3bd50a3702f86e7348de206b9fa3b95
(cherry picked from commit 581e6e5b8eb7c5f8d269f0d3154adaf12d66dbde)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix typo and misleading task name for nova-consoleauth

The services for console are installed in the 'Install nova
console/metadata services' task, however, the scheduler
install task misleadingly is named to mention that it installs
consoleauth and tries to run on the nova_consoleauth group
which does not exist.

Change-Id: If7c00cbfe3bd50a3702f86e7348de206b9fa3b95
(cherry picked from commit 581e6e5b8eb7c5f8d269f0d3154adaf12d66dbde)

commit_message:
Watcher restarts watching resources in failure

kuryr-kubernetes watcher watches k8s resources and trigger registered
pipeline.

This patch handles restarting watching when watch thread has failed.

Change-Id: I27a719a326dc37f97c46b88d0c171d0f12ded605
Closes-Bug: 1739776
Related-Bug: 1705429
Signed-off-by: Eunsoo Park <esevan.park@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 58e6b1914c516ec87e04cfc935f33352887d1926)

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Ieee3ce37403ce63e332178cc15f13cf9905b684e

commit_message:
Add oslo.log into requirements.txt

We are recently switching to oslo.log [1] but didn't add it to the
requirements. The missing of oslo.log causes failure of zun-ui gate.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/540222/

Change-Id: Ic6518d2c5ad3764d2c21999a616dc9c9625ada6e

commit_message:
Cast division product to int when inflating auth

This makes the re-inflation logic for tokens behave the same,
regardless of running on python3 or python2.

Change-Id: I8f970af482fb3b54c55f2fdb251263949b3922d6

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-21 21:16:15.000000000', 'message': 'MariaDB: Update to version 10.2.13 - and patch broken script

Recent versions of MariaDB (10.1.31, 10.2.13) have a regression that
breaks clustering.  See https://github.com/MariaDB/server/pull/457 and
https://github.com/MariaDB/server/commit/4e6dab94d0931eafba502f5a91da29a54e75bb33
for an in depth explanation.

We need 10.2.13+ for Barbican to function correctly (see bug #1734329)
but we also need the fix above to support MariaDB clustering.

This work-around can be removed later on when MariaDB 10.2.x releases
contain the needed script fix.

Thanks to Sam Yample <sam@yaple.net> for helping track this down.

Change-Id: Ifd09d7effe7d382074ca9e6678df36bdd4bce0af

commit_message:
MariaDB: Update to 10.2.13; patching wsrep_sst_xtrabackup-v2

Recent versions of MariaDB (10.1.31, 10.2.13) have a regression that
breaks clustering.  See https://github.com/MariaDB/server/pull/457 and
https://github.com/MariaDB/server/commit/4e6dab94d0931eafba502f5a91da29a54e75bb33
for an in depth explanation.

We need 10.2.13+ for Barbican to function correctly (see bug #1734329)
but we also need the fix above to support MariaDB clustering.

This work-around can be removed later on when MariaDB 10.2.x releases
contain the needed script fix.

Thanks to Sam Yample <sam@yaple.net> for helping track this down.

Change-Id: Ifd09d7effe7d382074ca9e6678df36bdd4bce0af

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-16 15:08:45.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Refine waiting for vif plug events during _hard_reboot"

This gets us back to Ib0cf5d55750f13d0499a570f14024dca551ed4d4
which was meant to address an issue introduced
by Id188d48609f3d22d14e16c7f6114291d547a8986.

So we essentially had three changes:

1. Hard reboot would blow away volumes and vifs and then wait for the
   vifs to be plugged; this caused a problem for some vif types (
   linuxbridge was reported) because the event never came and we
   timed out.

2. To workaround that, a second change was made to simply not wait for
   vif plugging events.

3. Since #2 was a bit heavy-handed for a problem that didn't impact
   openvswitch, another change was made to only wait for non-bridge vif
   types, so we'd wait for OVS.

But it turns out that opendaylight is an OVS vif type and doesn't send
events for plugging the vif, only for binding the port (and we don't
re-bind the port during reboot). There is also a report of this being a
problem for other types of ports, see
If209f77cff2de00f694b01b2507c633ec3882c82.

So rather than try to special-case every possible vif type that could
be impacted by this, we are simply reverting the change so we no longer
wait for vif plugged events during hard reboot.

Note that if we went back to Id188d48609f3d22d14e16c7f6114291d547a8986
and tweaked that to not unplug/plug the vifs we wouldn't have this
problem either, and that change was really meant to deal with an
encrypted volume issue on reboot. But changing that logic is out of the
scope of this change. Alternatively, we could re-bind the port during
reboot but that could have other implications, or neutron could put
something into the port details telling us which vifs will send events
and which won't, but again that's all outside of the scope of this
patch.

Change-Id: Ib3f10706a7191c58909ec1938042ce338df4d499
Closes-Bug: #1755890

commit_message:
Revert "Refine waiting for vif plug events during _hard_reboot"

This reverts commit e06ad602f3ef98c505e49078dd225dde2a79e2a1.

This gets us back to Ib0cf5d55750f13d0499a570f14024dca551ed4d4
which was meant to address an issue introduced
by Id188d48609f3d22d14e16c7f6114291d547a8986.

So we essentially had three changes:

1. Hard reboot would blow away volumes and vifs and then wait for the
   vifs to be plugged; this caused a problem for some vif types (
   linuxbridge was reported) because the event never came and we
   timed out.

2. To workaround that, a second change was made to simply not wait for
   vif plugging events.

3. Since #2 was a bit heavy-handed for a problem that didn't impact
   openvswitch, another change was made to only wait for non-bridge vif
   types, so we'd wait for OVS.

But it turns out that opendaylight is an OVS vif type and doesn't send
events for plugging the vif, only for binding the port (and we don't
re-bind the port during reboot). There is also a report of this being a
problem for other types of ports, see
If209f77cff2de00f694b01b2507c633ec3882c82.

So rather than try to special-case every possible vif type that could
be impacted by this, we are simply reverting the change so we no longer
wait for vif plugged events during hard reboot.

Note that if we went back to Id188d48609f3d22d14e16c7f6114291d547a8986
and tweaked that to not unplug/plug the vifs we wouldn't have this
problem either, and that change was really meant to deal with an
encrypted volume issue on reboot. But changing that logic is out of the
scope of this change. Alternatively, we could re-bind the port during
reboot but that could have other implications, or neutron could put
something into the port details telling us which vifs will send events
and which won't, but again that's all outside of the scope of this
patch.

Change-Id: Ib3f10706a7191c58909ec1938042ce338df4d499
Closes-Bug: #1755890

commit_message:
Check for container,disk_format on web-download

Fail image-create-via-import requests for the web-download import
method that don't include values for container_format or disk_format.

Closes-bug: #1757927

Change-Id: Ic5c81916823ff32f2dbddd32b40e825de0697dc9

commit_message:
[docs] Add changelog file

When Rally repo included both framework and all available plugins,
release notes for each release were huge and required a lot of different
sections. It is something which cannot be applied to this repo and we
can simplify release notes.

Let's use CHANGELOG.rst file to store notes for all releases.

Also, this patch removes original release notes of Rally project.

Add publish-zuul-docs job

This publishes zuul-related project documentation to zuul-ci.org.

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-February/127256.html

As stated in the mail, since there is mix and match for DPDK and non-DPDK VMs (SR-IOV and regular) in the same node, it is apt to keep the qemu running with "hugetlbfs" for all the VMs in the cluster when DPDK is enabled in one role. I am good when you are ready to merge.

You should also ensure the right directory with right permission is used for the vhost sockets.'}, {'account_id': 17280, 'date': '2018-02-19 16:20:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

We don't need the depends-on patch, but we do need something that modifies the permissions on the /var/run/openvswitch directory right?"}, {'account_id': 17280, 'date': '2018-02-19 16:39:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I guess you could use the depends-on patch to modify the directory permissions.  I'm not sure it is the right place to do it, since the OVS is the client here, but it should be OK since the class in puppet-neutron is specific to ODL."}, {'account_id': 18575, 'date': '2018-02-20 06:13:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> modifies the permissions on the /var/run/openvswitch directory

Can you consider using /var/lib/vhost_sockets directory instead? The reason is that, to avoid modifying the directories used by packaged scripts. If there is any scripts running part of package update, then it might change the directory access, not in our control.'}, {'account_id': 20866, 'date': '2018-02-21 06:01:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Workflow

commit_message:
Configure qemu group setting as hugetlbfs for ovs-dpdk

Till now, the ovs service file and ovs-ctl command files
are patched to allow ovs to run with qemu group. In order
to remove this workarounds, a new group hugetlbfs is created
which will be shared between ovs and qemu. This patch contains
the changes required for applying these changes.

Vhostuser Socket Directory is changed from
"/var/run/openvswitch" to "/var/lib/vhost_sockets" to avoid
modifying the directory access by packaged scripts.

Depends-On: I5fc2f852c66c2b825af96aba2657d0f9085dc8c3
Patch-url: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/547961/

Change-Id: Id727a514610816c8223aa0dcd49a70caec29a21d

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: I71e63d92728a50727f29dadf71fae3085f519ee7
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: Ic1b9387220068b394f8325e40002c3ba10ab85ea
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

subject: Use decimal type for start_time and end_time
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-20 00:03:58.000000000', 'message': 'Use decimal type for start_time and end_time

* Change start_time and end_time type in action model
* Add db migration script for start_time and end_time type change

Using float type for start_time and end_time caused inaccurate
timestamps to be stored [1].  This change uses decimal type for
start_time and end_time.

[1] https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/problems-with-float.html

Change-Id: Ia6c1f0a0379695edfbb9e6f32a1e799927f05fc3
Closes-Bug: #1746123
'}]
commit_message:
Use decimal type for start_time and end_time

* Change start_time and end_time type in action model
* Add db migration script for start_time and end_time type change

Using float type for start_time and end_time caused inaccurate
timestamps to be stored [1].  This change uses decimal type for
start_time and end_time.

[1] https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/problems-with-float.html

Change-Id: Ia6c1f0a0379695edfbb9e6f32a1e799927f05fc3
Closes-Bug: #1746123

[{'created': '2018-03-16 15:02:05.000000000', 'message': "Fix typo and misleading task name for nova-consoleauth

The services for console are installed in the 'Install nova
console/metadata services' task, however, the scheduler
install task misleadingly is named to mention that it installs
consoleauth and tries to run on the nova_consoleauth group
which does not exist.

Change-Id: If7c00cbfe3bd50a3702f86e7348de206b9fa3b95
(cherry picked from commit 581e6e5b8eb7c5f8d269f0d3154adaf12d66dbde)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix typo and misleading task name for nova-consoleauth

The services for console are installed in the 'Install nova
console/metadata services' task, however, the scheduler
install task misleadingly is named to mention that it installs
consoleauth and tries to run on the nova_consoleauth group
which does not exist.

Change-Id: If7c00cbfe3bd50a3702f86e7348de206b9fa3b95
(cherry picked from commit 581e6e5b8eb7c5f8d269f0d3154adaf12d66dbde)

commit_message:
Dell EMC SC: ISCSI initialize_connection fixes.

Driver was not honoring the server in ISCSI and returning connection
information for all servers (IQNs) connected to a volume.

If multiple servers are mapped to a volume the driver was only returning
the first server for a given portal.

Closes-Bug: #1756914
Change-Id: If65780000fa8f59f663b00b88584cf289effa590
(cherry picked from commit f8980ea128dd6698a1cb3a283d98b47371b854f6)

commit_message:
[Docs] Simplify overview page

This modifies the overview section to be one page instead of
4 long sections. We just refer to the architecture reference
for details about the architecture.

Change-Id: I1f5da9acaa677b2cd752cda30c33eba846a96eb4

commit_message:
Switch the CI to hardware types and clean up playbook

This change modifies the playbook to use the 'ipmi' hardware type.
It also removes redundant conditions. The job name is not changed
to simplify the patch.

Change-Id: I80c72564c31a6bea07b13f8bac13d1cba4a0845d

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: Ifcd69742e82eedc7f63857a3221cc382c1d58ee5
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

messages: [{'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-03-21 19:54:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-03-21 20:24:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-03-21 23:03:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1\n\nLGTM'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2018-03-22 16:19:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-21 19:54:43.000000000', 'message': "add openstack-tox-lower-constraints

Add a job for running tests for projects using their lower-constraints
list.

These settings are currently based on the ones from the py35 job
because we expect the tox environment to be configured to use python3
wherever that is possible.

We don't set this up as part of the check-requirements job template in
project-config because projects opt-in to running the tests.

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html

Change-Id: I8ad36dfd2ce6d0ab18340c58bd78d234c0d568e6
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
"}]
commit_message:
add openstack-tox-lower-constraints

Add a job for running tests for projects using their lower-constraints
list.

These settings are currently based on the ones from the py35 job
because we expect the tox environment to be configured to use python3
wherever that is possible.

We don't set this up as part of the check-requirements job template in
project-config because projects opt-in to running the tests.

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html

Change-Id: I8ad36dfd2ce6d0ab18340c58bd78d234c0d568e6
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Neutron: agent host targetting

This PS adds the ablity to target different configs to different
hosts for the nutron agents, in the same manner as nova-compute.

commit_message:
Add disable_ssl_certificate_validation to dashboard plugin

disable_ssl_certificate_validation in dashboard allows to disable
SSL certificate validation in horizon tempest plugin in cases where
validation is possible as IPv6 deployments when accessing using ip
instead of a dns name.

Change-Id: Iea7a4b85ac64572fac0f0ad871649a79fbc1c0f5
(cherry picked from commit 2e998fddf4d8eddce379d72ea625c79bc8bb6cfe)

commit_message:
Set osd_scenario and journals during ceph params conversion

This change adjust the ceph paramters conversion from puppet to
ceph-ansible to convert journals for non-collocated scenario and
always set the osd_scenario parameter.

Change-Id: I919fe8386c313246721e0e8193b3b11ae986a5e9
(cherry picked from commit 29ba7d1bcaf43e4c605de00371d9694fba69b331)

commit_message:
Follow the new PTI for document build

For compliance with the Project Testing Interface as described in:

https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/project-testing-interface.html

For more detials information, please refer to:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-December/125710.html

Note - there is still an issue with the use of autodoc_index_modules
being used to generate the module documentation. That is being worked
on separately. This at least fixes the docs jobs and gets things inline
with the current expected way to build docs.

Change-Id: Ib23f608723c616812f0e2397aa3373207ba92dfe

commit_message:
Remove dedicated network node for multinode, remove cloudwatch

* cloudwatch has been deprecated since Havana, removed in Queens
* chef pinning is relaxed to major versions
* remove dedicated network node for multinode testing

Change-Id: I397bf5e61d13d217206e07351b0dbb91125c3212

commit_message:
DNM: Run only tempest network tests

We've observed several tests failing when trying to ping/ssh a FIP.
This patch aims to exercise those tests and find the root cause.

Change-Id: Ibf0b95d7ce62abab1a937b22052db1e3057b30f5

commit_message:
Disable tripleo jobs voting

For the patches chained after this one we need to include new
binaries, and that breaks the tripleo rpm building system
which needs changes to the rpm spec files to include
those new binaries.

We can enable them back once the ovn migration agent patch
is merged.

Change-Id: Id8e7a5d0020be1ca1e175bc2b771273a695c7b6c

commit_message:
Set osd_scenario and journals during ceph params conversion

This change adjust the ceph paramters conversion from puppet to
ceph-ansible to convert journals for non-collocated scenario and
always set the osd_scenario parameter.

Change-Id: I919fe8386c313246721e0e8193b3b11ae986a5e9

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds

for more details.

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: I27b09081f7e8dad7209d91f431cf09fc30749e1d
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with check hyper-v

- nova-dsvm-full-tempest http://cloudbase-ci.com//nova/534866/1/ : FAILURE in 3h 21m 53s'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-01-17 22:25:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

This is one approach, and (if the assumptions are found to be non-crazy) probably the more efficient in terms of database processing etc.

But reducing all the providers' tweakables (min/max unit, etc.) to "common denominators" makes me pretty uncomfortable.  I'd have to see some real-world scenarios, but I suspect this will kill a lot of the flexibility of having those tweakables available for use in the first place.

Another approach would be to leave completely out of the sql the part of the calculation that relates to the requested amount, and just get back the amount *available* for each RP/RC.  Then *after* the query, start dot-producting those guys together to figure out which permutations (of all sets of those results under the umbrella of groups of providers related by tree/aggregate) will satisfy the requested amounts.

Big picture - and this would work for all scenarios, whether trees, aggregated sharing RPs, etc. - would look kinda like this:

- Get all provider "groupings" known to placement.  A "grouping" would be the list of all providers connected to each other with one degree of separation.  So all in the same tree, plus all associated via aggregate with any member of that tree.  Sometimes (maybe even often) this will wind up being one provider in the "grouping".  So be it.  (Optimization: if you must, winnow this down to only groupings which collectively provide the requested resource classes.  And/or collectively have the requested traits.)
- For each individual RP+RC in each grouping, calculate its available amount, figuring in total, allocation ratio, and current usage.  (Optimization: If you must, filter out the ones that wind up <=0 here.)  And figure out the discrete set of possible ways those amounts can be allocated - roughly range(max(min_unit, amount), min(max_unit, amount), step_size).
- For a given RC in a given grouping, figure out all the permutations of those possibilities such that the requested amount is satisfied (dot-products whose sums equal the requested amount).  If there are zero such permutations, there are no candidates from this grouping.
- Repeat for all RPs & RCs in the grouping.  Now we have one or more permutations for each resource class in the grouping.  Dot-product *those* together and you've got all the allocation requests possible in the grouping.
- Repeat for all groupings.  Add the sets together.  Now you have all your allocation requests.
- Construct provider summaries.  The providers therein will be the union of all "groupings" that had at least one resulting allocation request.  Here we don't need to worry about whether a provider in a grouping actually *provided* any resource in the allocation request - it gets included by virtue of being associated with the grouping.

I think this isn't *too* far off of what's being done now, except that it seems like we're trying to embed a lot of the filtering/selection logic into the SQL, and the result is code that only two or three people can even read, let alone understand well enough to debug/maintain.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-01-17 23:09:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2018-01-18 01:04:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:
