commit_message:
Fix doc builds

The updated releasenote and requirements jobs expect requirements for
docs in one of the requirements files. Move requirements from setup.cfg
to doc/requirements.txt file.

See also
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/project-testing-interface.html#documentation

Change-Id: Ic454831a80f799c2be5ba3089001f31f68c39f85

[{'created': '2018-02-19 09:56:23.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Fix failure when adding a speaker to an agent

When the peer has no auth_type set, we need to add it.

Also add a test that shows the broken behaviour.

Change-Id: I668397be4a531ba5c0628eb23df9a84d0de8c28c
Closes-Bug: 1750121
'}, {'created': '2018-02-20 11:04:36.000000000', 'message': 'Fix failure when adding a speaker to an agent

When get_bgp_speaker_with_advertised_routes() collects the data for BGP
peers, it needs to include the auth_type field, otherwise adding the
speaker to an agent will fail.

Change-Id: I668397be4a531ba5c0628eb23df9a84d0de8c28c
Closes-Bug: 1750121
'}]
commit_message:
Fix failure when adding a speaker to an agent

When get_bgp_speaker_with_advertised_routes() collects the data for BGP
peers, it needs to include the auth_type field, otherwise adding the
speaker to an agent will fail.

Change-Id: I668397be4a531ba5c0628eb23df9a84d0de8c28c
Closes-Bug: 1750121

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-08 01:39:48.000000000', 'message': 'Handle not found error on taking snapshot

If there is a request to create a snapshot of an instance and
another request to delete the instance at the same time, the
snapshot task might fail with libvirt error and this error
is not handled correctly by compute manager. As a result,
tracestack was printed in the compute log.

This patch fixes it by handling libvirt exception during live
snapshot and raise instance not found exception if the libvirt
exception is raised due to domain not found.

Change-Id: I585b7b03753ed1d28a313ce443e6918687d76a8b
Closes-Bug: #1722571
(cherry picked from commit 9ef56fa86639f97f63d853dbb2213415dcd5691b)
'}]
commit_message:
Handle not found error on taking snapshot

If there is a request to create a snapshot of an instance and
another request to delete the instance at the same time, the
snapshot task might fail with libvirt error and this error
is not handled correctly by compute manager. As a result,
tracestack was printed in the compute log.

This patch fixes it by handling libvirt exception during live
snapshot and raise instance not found exception if the libvirt
exception is raised due to domain not found.

Change-Id: I585b7b03753ed1d28a313ce443e6918687d76a8b
Closes-Bug: #1722571
(cherry picked from commit 9ef56fa86639f97f63d853dbb2213415dcd5691b)

commit_message:
Change object_audit_location_generator() to yield for a single policy.

auditor.py currently relies on POLICY[0] object_audit_location_generator()
to yield an AuditLocation for all policies on the object-server.

The changes in this patch are :
  - object_audit_location_generator() yields AuditLocation only for the
  requested policy
  - audit_all_objects() calls object_audit_location_generator() for each
    policy

Closes-Bug: 1534212
Change-Id: Ida92ba0a5e1e486a4f7132c6539460b38c34ec87

commit_message:
Fix ipv6 certificate to make it compliant with IDNA

Currently we are setting "DNS.0 = ::1", but ::1 is not a valid
A-Label for IDNA so the certificate is not correct.

Additionally, we are setting wrong value for DNS.0 = 127.0.0.1
in the ipv4 certificate.

Finally, removing issuerAltName from both ipv4 and ipv6 certificates
as they are not needed for the jobs.

New versions of python-cryptography are more strict to check
certificates content and does not allow to have not compliant
DNS names so we need to fix the certificate to bump python-cryptography.

Note that horizont tempest plugin does not support ipaddress SANs based
certificate validation so I'm disablint certificate validation for
dashboard in this patch.

Depends-On: Iea7a4b85ac64572fac0f0ad871649a79fbc1c0f5

Change-Id: Ib519d222e07e26d3683b24359e2f67728cdd8029

[{'created': '2018-03-21 03:22:41.000000000', 'message': 'Fix default partition type

There was a typo in I6b819a8071389e7e4eb4874ff7750bd192695ff2 that
modified this default partition type from "0x83" to just 83.  We are
now seeing failures relating to this as sfdisk checks for a "disk
manager" when it see Id 0x53 (== 83)

     Device Boot      Start         End      Blocks   Id  System
  /dev/vda1   *        2048    26664575    13331264   53  OnTrack DM6 Aux3

Restore to 0x83

Change-Id: Ib43038d2d740fbe01a21a13dd56367f7bc97f869
'}, {'created': '2018-03-21 23:11:02.000000000', 'message': 'Fix default partition type

modified this default partition type from "0x83" to just 83.  We are
now seeing failures relating to this as sfdisk checks for a "disk
manager" when it see Id 0x53 (== 83)

     Device Boot      Start         End      Blocks   Id  System
  /dev/vda1   *        2048    26664575    13331264   53  OnTrack DM6 Aux3

Restore to 0x83

Change-Id: Ib43038d2d740fbe01a21a13dd56367f7bc97f869
'}]
commit_message:
Fix default partition type

There was a typo in I6b819a8071389e7e4eb4874ff7750bd192695ff2 that
modified this default partition type from "0x83" to just 83.  We are
now seeing failures relating to this as sfdisk checks for a "disk
manager" when it see Id 0x53 (== 83)

     Device Boot      Start         End      Blocks   Id  System
  /dev/vda1   *        2048    26664575    13331264   53  OnTrack DM6 Aux3

Restore to 0x83

Change-Id: Ib43038d2d740fbe01a21a13dd56367f7bc97f869

commit_message:
Add tests to the service role

* Document the optionality in the defaults
* validate the input in the tasks before it's templated
* Standardize on the exec(starts,stops,reloads} interface
* Update the readme
* Add functional test

Yes, that is my point.'}, {'account_id': 27577, 'date': '2018-03-09 09:30:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> (1 comment)

But one question: what if didnot config image_driver_list in config file(/etc/zun/zun.conf) ?'}, {'account_id': 22076, 'date': '2018-03-09 09:42:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> > (1 comment)
 > 
 > But one question: what if didnot config image_driver_list in config
 > file(/etc/zun/zun.conf) ?
Here is a image_driver_list, it is the default configuration.
in zun/conf/image_driver.py
image_driver_list              = ['glance', 'docker']

Here could be configured as another image driver. So it's better to delete the image according to the image driver in the image_driver_list."}, {'account_id': 27577, 'date': '2018-03-12 08:29:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 27577, 'date': '2018-03-12 08:38:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 22406, 'date': '2018-03-12 10:07:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Adds image delete to server side

This patch adds image delete to server side for deleting
pulled image in docker img or glance image.

Implements: blueprint support-image-delete

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/zun/+spec/support-image-delete

Change-Id: I735783aa57925c7593c52a63d590fe93cf22d7c4

commit_message:
WIP of a stack/register machine for de/re/compiling a workflow

This removes the usage of the function call stack allowing
for much larger workflows to be deconsructed.

Change-Id: I9c9c26e09478439f3f2df6a5b379ffdc4fb2ec82

commit_message:
Make it easier to restart/resume a prior reverted flow

When a prior flow has been reverted, the default behavior
is to revert all the things in that flow and start as if
it is new but in the case where instead the partial work
completed previously still can be used it is only useful to
reset the REVERTED nodes instead and start those back up
instead.

Change-Id: I3b3276aa57f017d499f8a09a4675b7af51703355

))'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2016-03-10 18:34:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

So I guess this kind of flies in the face of the openstack coding guidelines a little.  What I'd probably rather see is all of the constants bundled into a tasfklow/constants.py or something.  Some of them might should be grouped into namedtuples of common things, like:

from taskflow.constants import TASK_STATES
if task.state == TASK_STATES.PENDING:
    # blah blah blah

I dunno, what do you think?  I've seen things organized like that in other projects and greatly preferred it to how we have constants littered everywhere in the codebase."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2016-02-23 02:30:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Remove some of the silly import renames (task_atom, retry_atom)

Instead of doing these somewhat silly import aliases just import
from these modules directly what is needed (typically constants
or class objects) and use those directly instead. This makes a
few less silly imports needed/used and makes the world happier by
doing that.

Change-Id: I8b51bc34b4a697d595bbac43402630aaab7e8218

commit_message:
Add metrics to workers so that selection functions can be smarter

Start to add metrics to each worker (and perform some identity cleanup
at the same time) so that worker selection functions can make better
decisions about which worker to pick.

Change-Id: I7861925ff55816a6dfa15ceda14a08e96f1baab3

commit_message:
Make it easier to switch out the WBE worker selector

Allow for providing a custom function that users can
give to the engine and that function will be expected
to return one of the workers that can best perform the
given task (if any).

Change-Id: Ib8d671f9dfcb50e239a98f0f37e6c4a51a834b27

commit_message:
Protect state machine storage access better

Put guards on the state-machine reaction functions
so that they can be better protected from any externally
triggered storage changes.

Change-Id: I4e9d2b4819549e3d84a1157b1f9968a61ed68b8e

commit_message:
Split off completion state-changing from '_safe_change_state'

The '_safe_change_state' complexity and code is not needed
for completion of atoms, so avoid going through the same code
path. This makes the code less confusing and easier to understand
and read/follow.

Change-Id: I4f8acc4419644f4c867827e1b4da8e9d6da41305

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-01-28 20:12:56.000000000', 'message': 'Handle futurist rejected execution submission exceptions

Futurist executors (which derive from the ones taskflow
uses) support rejecting submitted work due to various policies
so handle when one of these exceptions is thrown instead of
just aborting the engine.

This allows for those policies to correctly be handled when
they are raised by the executor that the engine was provided
with.

Change-Id: I5581d3a055945317fe0930842db3c8c14656a8ba
'}, {'created': '2016-01-29 02:16:59.000000000', 'message': 'Handle futurist rejected execution submission exceptions (WIP)

of these exceptions is thrown instead of just aborting the engine.

Change-Id: I5581d3a055945317fe0930842db3c8c14656a8ba
'}, {'created': '2016-01-29 19:41:22.000000000', 'message': 'Handle rejected execution submission exceptions better

Futurist executors (which derive from the ones taskflow uses) support
rejecting submitted work due to various policies so handle when one
of these exceptions is thrown instead of just aborting the engine. Also
concurrent.futures executors can throw runtime error if they have been
shutdown during engine usage (such a thing can happen if a user provides
a executor and they are using it for other out of engine activity).

This allows for those policies to correctly be handled when they are
raised by the executor that the engine was provided with.

Change-Id: I5581d3a055945317fe0930842db3c8c14656a8ba
'}, {'created': '2016-01-29 19:43:06.000000000', 'message': 'Handle rejected execution submission exceptions better

Futurist executors (which derive from the ones taskflow uses) support
rejecting submitted work due to various policies so handle when one
of these exceptions is thrown instead of just aborting the engine. Also
concurrent.futures executors can throw runtime error if they have been
shutdown during engine usage (such a thing can happen if a user provides
a executor and they are using it for other out of engine activity).

This allows for those policies to correctly be handled when they are
raised by the executor that the engine was provided with.

Change-Id: I5581d3a055945317fe0930842db3c8c14656a8ba

of these exceptions is thrown instead of just aborting the engine. Also

shutdown during engine usage (such a thing can happen if a user provides
a executor and they are using it for other out of engine activity).

This allows for those policies to correctly be handled when they are
raised by the executor that the engine was provided with.

Change-Id: I5581d3a055945317fe0930842db3c8c14656a8ba

commit_message:
Handle rejected execution submission exceptions better

Futurist executors (which derive from the ones taskflow uses) support
rejecting submitted work due to various policies so handle when one
of these exceptions is thrown instead of just aborting the engine. Also
concurrent.futures executors can throw runtime error if they have been
shutdown during engine usage (such a thing can happen if a user provides
a executor and they are using it for other out of engine activity).

This allows for those policies to correctly be handled when they are
raised by the executor that the engine was provided with.

Closes-Bug: #1540549

Change-Id: I5581d3a055945317fe0930842db3c8c14656a8ba

commit_message:
Make the completer resume() function easier to understand

This also makes it be able to handle resuming in a more
iterative manner (vs one that has to grab all the atoms states
at once).

It also adds more trace logging around the resumption
activities which is useful for figuring out what is or isn't
happening.

Change-Id: I06a8e2a8e2cef27b31c380b2641c3dff59977a8f

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-01-22 01:50:55.000000000', 'message': "Add task 'critical' attribute (WIP)

Glance has a task subclass they are using that makes tasks
not critical but it has limitations in that such task has
to wrap exceptions that are triggered and not raise them for
the taskflow engine to continue on.

To make this pattern more 'standard' have a attribute on
tasks that allows a task to denote whether it is critical or
whether it is not (default to critical to retain the existing
behavior). When a task is marked as not critical it will be
able to fail and not trigger the engine itself to stop scheduling
further work.

Code from glance that inspired this change is at:

https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/stable/liberty/\
        glance/async/utils.py

Change-Id: I718a11fd5e65365d5423045e51e657708781878c

commit_message:
Add task 'critical' attribute

Glance has a task subclass they are using that makes tasks
not critical but it has limitations in that such task has
to wrap exceptions that are triggered and not raise them for
the taskflow engine to continue on.

To make this pattern more 'standard' have a attribute on
tasks that allows a task to denote whether it is critical or
whether it is not (default to critical to retain the existing
behavior). When a task is marked as not critical it will be
able to fail and not trigger the engine itself to stop scheduling
further work.

Code from glance that inspired this change is at:

https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/stable/liberty/\
        glance/async/utils.py

Change-Id: I718a11fd5e65365d5423045e51e657708781878c

commit_message:
Add new complete finished atoms state/reaction handler

Instead of having the analyze function complete atoms
have a new state that is responsible for completing finished
atoms that were finished in the waiting state; this new
completion function then once it has finished up then transitions
the machine into the analysis state (which then finds follow-up
work and so-on).

Change-Id: I28f684cd9e3c4efe84421c737067a626cb2d81ec

commit_message:
POC of a different atom internal format

This internal format can allow for different atom
external formats/versions by having a conversion
function and internal object format that can stay
the same (even if the external format/version changes).

Does not work yet (but WIP)...

Change-Id: Ibdf5437c8981099c9c9929bbca05c5bee6d017b9

commit_message:
Atom initiated suspension

Allow atoms that are running inside an engine
to request that the engine suspend itself when
the engine is able to do so.

Part of fixes for bug #1527678

Change-Id: I382aef9c9533c8a684de3841fea09af1ed2f4052

commit_message:
Remove need for local failure storage cache

Atom details already retain the failure that
includes the traceback (unless they are reloaded
from there backing storage) so we don't need
to double cache them in storage.

Change-Id: Ia3cfdf225252456cced65babe1431b7b437fd7a3

On further consideration, what are we trying to solve with this?  Having to check two lists every time seems kind of tedious.  Could what you're trying to solve work better with a flag on the Failure object? Then you could still get all of the failures with one property.  Or maybe add an @property for 'failures' that returns iterutils.chain(self.internal_failiures, self.external_failures) so if you just want them all you can still do that?"}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2016-01-13 17:11:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

We can do the flag (good idea), the idea for this was to hopefully make it easier to denote what failures are user triggered/caused and what ones are engine triggered/caused. A flag though on the failure object seems like it can also do this (which then we can use for logging to say X internal failures happened and Y external failures happened and so on).'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2016-01-13 17:52:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-01-13 21:07:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified-1

[{'created': '2015-12-15 01:31:01.000000000', 'message': 'Disallow and raise on duplicate conductor run calls

It is not recommended to have conductor run being called
twice from various endpoints (two threads for example)
so proactively enforce that by raising an exception if that
situation is encountered.

Change-Id: Ia145e0e89df3196ec55136b2970c599e84e556f2
'}]
commit_message:
Disallow and raise on duplicate conductor run calls

It is not recommended to have conductor run being called
twice from various endpoints (two threads for example)
so proactively enforce that by raising an exception if that
situation is encountered.

Change-Id: Ia145e0e89df3196ec55136b2970c599e84e556f2

[{'created': '2018-03-20 13:59:48.000000000', 'message': 'Introduce rootwrap and filter

This patch make Zun leverage Rootwrap. In particular, it does
the following:
* Setup Rootwrap in the Zun devstack plugin

(cherry picked from commit d412de7100058f4a362cf58bd11f88b31b500f77)

commit_message:
Introduce rootwrap and filter

If the zun-compute process is owned by a user who doesn't have
passwordless sudo privilege, zun-compute will fail to run
privileged command (e.g. sudo privsep-helper ...).

A native solution is to grant passwordless sudo to the user
who owns the zun process, but the best practice is to leverage
Rootwrap [1], which can restrict the privilege escalation.

This patch make Zun leverage Rootwrap. In particular, it does
the following:
* Setup Rootwrap in the Zun devstack plugin
* Introduce a sample rootwrap config file
* Introduce sample rootwrap filters for executing privsep-helper
* Introduce a root helper which basically adds "sudo zun-rootwrap"
  to the beginning of the command to be execute.
* Initialize privsep to use the Zun's root helper

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Rootwrap

Closes-Bug: #1749342
Needed-By: I69c47d25fa53f8e08efad9daa71d2f550425a5e7
Change-Id: I3ca5d853588b3705cb6cb2410df16e16a621c030
(cherry picked from commit d412de7100058f4a362cf58bd11f88b31b500f77)

commit_message:
Add network-list to zunclient

This change adds network list support to the python-zunclient project
for the network-list command.

The zun command network-list is now:
    zun network-list <container>

Change-Id: I59f1fc63989796a1623ebc62c0dfae8e2dd33be8

commit_message:
zun rebuild on local node

Provide reconstruction function, if the container A is damaged,
users can use this function to recreate a container B.
The container B and A use the same resources, such as network, CPU, etc.

Co-Authored-By: Hongbin Lu <hongbin034@gmail.com>

Change-Id: Ic186499798dbe7935626f37ef92493fe87922605
Implements:blueprint zun-rebuild-on-local-node

@Sean people are actually hitting this issue because this affects Nova live migrations, and I know because I did the RCA that found this issue as well as the Nova issue [1] where they assume idempotency on the initialize connection action, and even if Nova is working on a fix [2] that would remove the issue, it is always best to have an idempotent initialize_connection method on the driver itself.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1754716

commit_message:
Dell EMC SC: ISCSI initialize_connection fixes.

Driver was not honoring the server in ISCSI and returning connection
information for all servers (IQNs) connected to a volume.

If multiple servers are mapped to a volume the driver was only returning
the first server for a given portal.

Closes-Bug: #1756914
Change-Id: If65780000fa8f59f663b00b88584cf289effa590

commit_message:
Revert "Changed MariaDB version to 10.2.13"

This reverts commit 81bf5f3656f12b6f8279329edcf91ef63e7a6b5f back to
MariaDB 10.1.23 which we know works with clustering enabled
(pod.replicas.server > 1).

Change-Id: Ibf70dbab78f03d32e1ec96e99ac8db59d23cb96e

[{'created': '2018-02-01 14:04:37.000000000', 'message': 'DS8K: correct in-use replication vol status

Correct in-use replication volume status after failover/failback.
Currently the status of in-use replication volume is changed to
available after failover in ds8k cinder driver to make the replication
volume can be attached again after failover. So does failback operation.
However, nova is using the new cinder attach api right now. The in-use
volume can not be attached to the same instance again even the volume
status is changed to available and attach_status is changed to detached
in cinder driver by force. This is due to nova stores the combined
relationship of volume_id and instance.uuid in nova db as
BlockDeviceMapping. This is to avoid attaching the same volume to the
same instance twice. So the attaching request can not be sent to cinder
if there is attached record in BlockDeviceMapping between the volume and
instance. So this patch keeps replication volume status during failover
and faiback.

Change-Id: Ia66d3522bbe107fb7ab077ab948393c2b7f34737
Closes-Bug: 1746732

commit_message:
DS8K: correct in-use replication vol status

Correct in-use replication volume status after failover/failback.
Currently the status of in-use replication volume is changed to
available after failover in ds8k cinder driver to make sure the
replication volume can be attached again after failover. So does
failback operation. However, nova is using the new cinder attach
api right now. The in-use volume can not be attached to the same
instance again even the volume status is changed to available and
attach_status is changed to detached in cinder driver by force.
This is due to nova stores the combined relationship of volume_id
and instance.uuid in nova db as BlockDeviceMapping. This is to avoid
attaching the same volume to the same instance twice. So the
attaching request can not be sent to cinder if there is attached
record in BlockDeviceMapping between the volume and instance. So this
patch keeps replication volume status during failover and faiback.

Change-Id: Ia66d3522bbe107fb7ab077ab948393c2b7f34737
Closes-Bug: 1746732

[{'created': '2018-03-21 16:13:47.000000000', 'message': 'Make default own_shard_range have state ACTIVE

Only an unsharded root container will have no own_shard_range in
its shard ranges table. When creating a default own_shard_range it
is useful for it to be in state ACTIVE.

Change-Id: Ic4925a04be0b7c498e80beeb5c8d77d77df2826a
'}]
commit_message:
Make default own_shard_range have state ACTIVE

Only an unsharded root container will have no own_shard_range in
its shard ranges table. When creating a default own_shard_range it
is useful for it to be in state ACTIVE.

Change-Id: Ic4925a04be0b7c498e80beeb5c8d77d77df2826a

messages:
[{'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2015-12-02 06:53:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2015-12-02 06:58:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-12-02 08:17:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified-1

Build failed (check pipeline).  For information on how to proceed, see http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html#automated-testing

- gate-taskflow-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/15/252215/2/check/gate-taskflow-pep8/ca361dc/ : SUCCESS in 1m 09s
- gate-taskflow-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/15/252215/2/check/gate-taskflow-docs/160f8e2//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 52s
- gate-taskflow-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/15/252215/2/check/gate-taskflow-python27/9787a07/ : FAILURE in 52m 11s
- gate-taskflow-python34 http://logs.openstack.org/15/252215/2/check/gate-taskflow-python34/b060358/ : FAILURE in 40m 29s
- gate-taskflow-pypy http://logs.openstack.org/15/252215/2/check/gate-taskflow-pypy/2137955/ : FAILURE in 1m 30s (non-voting)
- gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src-taskflow http://logs.openstack.org/15/252215/2/check/gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src-taskflow/52f63f8/ : SUCCESS in 1h 16m 10s'}, {'account_id': 9648, 'date': '2015-12-02 15:16:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I like the idea, and the implementation looks solid from my limited understanding of that part of the taskflow guts.  I do have one question, though.  How would this interact with a retry atom on the flow?  If you raise a Delay, does the retry get checked immediately or after the delay?  Could a retry potentially just REVERT the SUSPENDED task before it executes again?  If not, how hard would it be to let that happen?'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2015-12-02 19:30:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Right, agreed, needs some further work and cleanup.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2015-12-02 19:31:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Example that can be used with this:

https://gist.github.com/harlowja/a5928966223fb5d6e0e4'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2016-02-29 18:46:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2

The mitaka release is in feature freeze and only bug fixes for mitaka will be accepted until a stable branch is created. The -2 will be removed when a stable branch is created.'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2016-03-09 20:06:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

This project is now open for new features.'}, {'account_id': 9648, 'date': '2016-04-27 20:37:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Can we make a Retry atom that throws this exception to delay the retry of the subflow it is assigned to?  Does that make sense?  I am thinking this could solve the issues with the PollingFlow stuff I worked on.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2017-12-18 05:18:46.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Jenkins with the following votes:

* Verified-1 by Jenkins (3)
'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2018-03-22 01:05:49.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Add 'lock_factory' class attribute to action engine

To match how other classes provide '_event_factory'
and '_semaphore_factory' so that users of these components
can alter the impl. of these threading objects (say to
use green impls) it makes sense to mirror that attribute
changing ability in the action engine as well for its usage
of locks.

It also removes the lock used inside the compiler component
of the action engine, because the engine class itself protects
the usage of its compile() method with a lock already, so there
isn't much need to have another layer of locking as well.

Change-Id: I542aacd06afb63a6b100a1f6c23af5de7c4d8262

This adds a conditional that extracts certmonger's local CA if the
certificate doesn't exist or if it has expired already. This adds the
ability for the deployer to fix the undercloud installation with the
undercloud install command itself if expiration of the CA cert happens.

Conflicts:
    spec/classes/tripleo_certmonger_ca_local_spec.rb

The file above didn't exist in stable/newton

Change-Id: I61577be2434d7321dd462902d386c6911c2c4f57
Closes-Bug: #1753948
(cherry picked from commit a4ae09d169396f63b1952570b2105d695753fa9d)
"}]
commit_message:
Extract local CA if it expired

This adds a conditional that extracts certmonger's local CA if the
certificate doesn't exist or if it has expired already. This adds the
ability for the deployer to fix the undercloud installation with the
undercloud install command itself if expiration of the CA cert happens.

Conflicts:
    spec/classes/tripleo_certmonger_ca_local_spec.rb

The file above didn't exist in stable/newton

Change-Id: I61577be2434d7321dd462902d386c6911c2c4f57
Closes-Bug: #1753948
(cherry picked from commit a4ae09d169396f63b1952570b2105d695753fa9d)

commit_message:
Track dirtiness of models and use it during saving

Instead of having awkward logic to determine if a model
is dirty (its properties have changed since it was last
saved) we can do better by having a helper method that will
generate properties that when set/changed those changes
will affect a new 'dirty' property.

Change-Id: If620b230ac2188ce791a4c8b6e41ca03c04edd04

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2015-11-30 15:18:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2015-11-30 15:47:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2

I still against this change, oslo.messaging rpc delivery model is a "at-most-once" one.

That means from the client point of view that oslo.messaging will ensure that the server callback will never ever be called twice. (And yes perhaps it will be never called).

If we allow this "ack_then_process=False" into our API, if the application crash unexpectedly (segfault/kill -9/...), rabbitmq will send the message to another worker. And then, the message have been processed twice... (Even the first one have badly finish)
Then, a client sends a rpc request, rabbitmq delivers the message to worker1, then worker lost the connection to rabbit, the unack message returns to the queue. Then worker2 takes the message, worker1 connection comes back. Both workers returns a reply... Than doesn't smell good...
Also, client sends a rpc request, rabbitmq delivers the message to a worker, then the worker loss the connection to rabbit, the unack message returns to the queue. Then the connection come back, the same worker take the message, but this time, the message is dropped, because drivers implementation to ensure that 'at-most-once' delivery mode that oslo.messaging provides to the public API.

This change can't work without changing drivers implementation. Because they drop duplicate msg_id.

Race conditions that will be of introduced by this, depends of the Target() configuration and if this is a call or cast, if fanout is set, or/and if server is set. So I don't think from the public API point of view that should be a global dispatcher options that apply of all rpc method and Target() types.

I really would like to understand the use-case before seen this in oslo.messaging. We have already refuse this many times. The last one in my mind was for the Cinder HA stuffs, but finally Cinder choices an other better/more reliable solution instead of thinking that acknowledging messages after their process fix their HA issue.'}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2015-11-30 15:52:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2015-11-30 15:57:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

@Mehdi - That's a great point. We should document that design choice somewhere so we can stop having this conversation."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-11-30 16:42:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

All fine with me, I was trying to help some of the mistral folks here (who can hopefully jump on this review and respond); I poked them on IRC so hopefully they can get active here (since I think they wanted it and I was just trying to be helpful).'}, {'account_id': 11744, 'date': '2015-12-01 16:11:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I have to say that I'm also in agreement with Mehdi - even though the patch is simple and backward compatible.
Would be great for the Mistral team to answer Mehdi's questions (especially when the same message is redirected to another server for whatever reason).
Acknowledging after processing does not guarantee that the ACK will reach back to the sender (or the server could crash after committing the request but before the ACK is sent back), how is Mistral going to address this case properly? Hope that the 16 last ID history will filter out any potential further retry received?

Many people/projects have tried to make the infra handle this kind of HA feature "automatically" - in most cases as a convenient way to fill gaps left by apps - but this does not work 100%. The only way to handle this properly is to handle duplicates at the app server level in an atomic way  - meaning the app must have a safe way to distinguish duplicates for those requests that are not idempotent and nobody else (in case of multi server instances) can "commit" that same request during that verification window.

Using that option may make the vulnerability window smaller, but this also causes issues that are *much* harder to debug on the field when they happen (and they will)...

My concern with this kind of patch is that it may incite more apps to use that option (follow suit with what Mistral does) and we end up with a bigger problem in our hands. I would say it is better to fix the problem properly at the app level than delegate it to the infra with a false sense of correctness.'}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2015-12-02 09:35:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I responded on the email thread but will add my comment on here to keep the discussion in one place:

I've also looked into doing something like this for a use case very
similar to Mistral a few months back, and my investigation came to a
similar conclusion to what Medhi (sileht) commented on the above patch -
you can't do this this way because it changes the semantics of current cast and call methods based on how the server is declared without the client being aware - that's a bad way to design an API.

What I came up with as a possible design back then, in case you want to use oslo.messaging to dispatch async tasks that should be done at least once (for example to be safe against worker crashing), is add a new method (in addition to cast() and call()) to the oslo.messaging client interface.

For example - we may want to call it something like ensure() or similar so that it is clear what the semantics are, and we want to be careful to not tie it's semantics to the AMQP model too much.

To Alec's point above we would also have to be clear that there would be nothing stopping you from receiving several of the same message in AMQP backed implementations.

I haven't looked into how it can be implemented in depth, but it would
surely be more than your patch, as you would need to evolve
several interfaces in oslo.messaging to make this happen."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2015-12-02 11:05:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I see that the patch scope is not enough. Although it would be nice to
have it demonstrated by the simple example... Anyway, we should address
all of the concerns raised here in the spec.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2015-12-02 11:06:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Commit message was updated'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2015-12-02 11:06:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-12-02 12:48:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified+1

(Nikola):
   "I've also looked into doing something like this for a use case very similar to Mistral a few months back, and my investigation came to a similar conclusion
   to what Medhi (sileht) commented on the above patch - you can't do this this way because it changes the semantics of current cast and call methods 
   based on how the server is declared without the client being aware"

Well not exactly, after the changes the behavior of the existing servers will be unchanged because the default (ack_then_process=True) is to ack before processing (same as old code). But if somebody changes an existing server to set that optional argument to False (without changing the client code) then yes, there is a *slight* change of behavior in that an ACK reception by the sender will henceforth indicate with certainty that the server has committed the request. While with the previous mode an ACK reception does not guarantee anything (which made it pretty much useless).
Given that existing client code likely do not handle ACK time out events anyway, the net result is that this change will not make any difference (won't make the system better or worst in case of failures).


(Nikola):
      "What I came up with as a possible design back then, in case you want to use oslo.messaging to dispatch async tasks that should be done at least once (for example to be safe against worker crashing), is add a new method (in addition to cast() and call()) to the oslo.messaging client interface.

      For example - we may want to call it something like ensure() or similar so that it is clear what the semantics are, and we want to be careful to not tie it's semantics to the AMQP model too much."

Well what you suggest is "at least once as much as possible but possibly more than once" with a success indicating a sure commit by the server.
 
That ensure() function will have to handle its own ACK timer and its own retry - with the caveat discussed above i.e.  the server *must* handle duplicate requests properly.
Moreover, ensure() can return an error/event that says "did not receive the ACK in X msec after Y attempts" but even so it cannot guarantee that the corresponding request was not in fact committed by the server.

(Nikola):
    "To Alec's point above we would also have to be clear that there would be nothing stopping you from receiving several of the same message in AMQP backed implementations."

That is not specific to AMQP as you will have exactly the same issue with zeroMQ for example.

(Nikola):
     "I haven't looked into how it can be implemented in depth, but it would surely be more than your patch, as you would need to evolve several interfaces in oslo.messaging to make this happen."

As mentioned above. You can't fix this just by adding code in oslo messaging and below. This convenient approach has been tried many times before by many projects outside of openstack and never worked.
The application has to bite the bullet and implement request idempotence properly on the server side. With multiple server instances and the use of RabbitMQ, that is more difficult because of the load balancing/distribution. Nobody else can do that for the app.

The current situation in openstack is pretty stark. Most of the services that use oslo messaging do not behave/recover properly in case of failures: many senders do not even retry sending and servers do not handle duplicates properly. And the reason is that the code assumes that there is an "at least once and at most once guarantee" under all conditions, which is clearly not true.'}, {'account_id': 11744, 'date': '2015-12-03 01:23:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Would be great to hear from the Mistral team and see what they had in mind (how would they implement this - assuming we move the ack post processing). I think I have an idea on what they want to do but would like to get confirmation from the team.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2015-12-03 09:47:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

"That is not specific to AMQP as you will have exactly the same issue with zeroMQ for example."

  Yaar, it specific to *all* distributed messaging systems ;]
( http://bravenewgeek.com/you-cannot-have-exactly-once-delivery/ )

PS. I asked Renat Akhmerov to comment.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2015-12-03 09:59:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Just for the record: I 100% agree with that the only way to handle this properly is to handle duplicates at the app server level in an atomic (or idempotent) way  - meaning the app must have a safe way to distinguish duplicates for those requests that are not idempotent and nobody else"

But the library must allow the app to implement this, isn't it? W/o ack_then_process = false that just cannot be done by the app using this library. And IIUC, the patch is exactly about that - just allow apps to implement that they need. We don't try to handle duplicates in Oslo.messaging and never should, yes.'}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2015-12-08 20:03:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> Well what you suggest is "at least once as much as possible but possibly more than once" with a success indicating a sure commit by the server.
 
> That ensure() function will have to handle its own ACK timer and its own retry - with the caveat discussed above i.e.  the server *must* handle duplicate requests properly.
Moreover, ensure() can return an error/event that says "did not receive the ACK in X msec after Y attempts" but even so it cannot guarantee that the corresponding request was not in fact committed by the server.

Right - so some of this stuff can be helped by rabbit as it can redeliver unacked messages, flag redelivered messages, and also notices dead connections. Ultimately, of course, you are right - application needs to be aware of possible duplicate messages, and handle network failures. But that is exactly my point - these constraints should be clearly expressed in the messaging API. That's why I think adding a flag only on the server side is not a good solution - it lets application easily get away with not doing it's job.

> The current situation in openstack is pretty stark. Most of the services that use oslo messaging do not behave/recover properly in case of failures: many senders do not even retry sending and servers do not handle duplicates properly. And the reason is that the code assumes that there is an "at least once and at most once guarantee" under all conditions, which is clearly not true.

Well I personally always considered the current way oslo.messaging does cast() was by design. In Nova for example, we don't retry messages, but we do have periodic tasks that clean up state (messages only last for 60 seconds using rabbit oslo.messaging driver anyway). This is mostly fine for Nova if not very elegant (*), the rationale being - if an instance fails to spawn - users can just start a new one.

For mistral this is obviously not the case due to the type of service it tries to provide. This is exactly what led me to conclude that we really need a different messaging API than what some more forgiving "customers" such as Nova use. 

(*) Nova has a DB in the middle that is really supposed to work all the time or all bets are off. Not all is great though - we have a known bugs especially with features that require orchestrating an action between several services.'}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2015-12-08 20:16:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> But the library must allow the app to implement this, isn't it? W/o ack_then_process = false that just cannot be done by the app using this library. And IIUC, the patch is exactly about that - just allow apps to implement that they need. We don't try to handle duplicates in Oslo.messaging and never should, yes.

As explained in the previos comment (response to Alec) I don't think that's enough. We want to design the API the app uses in such a way that it's really hard to write a server that does the wrong thing. Obviously, folks who know what they are doing will be happy with the flag. You can always use kombu (or pika) directly and have all the power you need (I think that's what taskflow does). 

But if we are extending a messaging library that provides abstractions for versioned RPC messages, it seems it would be poor design to bolt on such complex semantics (retry, redelivery, idempotency etc.) onto an API that was not meant to handle any of it."}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2015-12-09 11:50:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Wooh... A lot of comments. Let me read all that and get back with my comments.'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2015-12-10 08:18:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Ok, below are my explanations and comments.

Background:
Mistral is based on a worker model where an instance of engine distributes certain jobs (actions in Mistral terminology) across workers (executors in Mistral terms). At-most-once model is what we have now due to "ack before processing" model existing in oslo.messaging. From the very beginning we've considered it a bad model because it seems to be hard to recover from loosing workers (or connections with them which from arch perspective is the same thing). If a worker that took a message died right after that we didn't process the message. Moreover, our users observe this behaviour in real production environments.

For that matter, "at-least-once" model is preferred in our case because:

* If a Mistral action (job) doesn't change state of anything we can repeat it safely (for example, if we just get a list of VMs from Nova). Mistral provides tons of actions of this type.
* More generically, if an action is idempotent it's also safe to perform it more than once. Even if it changes state of something (e.g. an external system). Such actions often can be implemented in a way that they check state first and then do their job based on that check. Some of our users do implement such actions. Of course, it includes a number of aspects related to concurrent processing etc.
* Even if an action is not idempotent then a workflow itself can be implemented in a way to check for inconsistent state (resulted from an action being executed twice) at critical points and if so Mistral can report about it and stop the workflow thereby allowing to manually fix the state of environment and recover the workflow from that exact point.

Answering to Mahdi:

I agree with you on:
* Returning the result twice from different workers doesn't smell good. That's why I now think it should be rather an additional method like "distribute" that would target for this kind of asynchronous processing. It is semantically different, I fully agree. It's simply a different messaging pattern. This method maybe shouldn't even return anything.

I tend to disagree with you on:
* When you say "oslo.messaging rpc delivery is a 'at-most-once'" then my question is: Isn't oslo.messaging supposed to implement different messaging patterns and abstract from concrete messaging technologies (MQ brokers etc.)? There's a lot of different patterns for different cases (it's enough to look at RabbitMQ reference doc to see that), for example there's an established pattern called "Work queue" which is exactly what we're are pursuing. RPC is just one pattern. Maybe I misunderstand the mission oslo.messaging. Tell me if so.

How we got here (involves a little bit of politics, sorry for that):
Initially when we realized oslo.messaging didn't support what we needed we had a couple of conversations with oslo team members and saw that we wouldn't get this functionality any time soon. So we started working on our own implementation of messaging layer (much simpler than oslo.messaging and very specific to Mistral so it doesn't mean to duplicate it). When it got revealed we got a strong push back from some folks who said "The right way is to support it in oslo.messaging". So we decided to stop working on our own stuff (although it was about to completed) and find ways to squeeze it into oslo.
I'm saying this not because I'm surprised, we all know well how community works. I'm just hoping that it will start a broader discussion within oslo.messaging community so that you can clarify the situation and maybe even clarify the mission of the project regarding what patterns you support and why them. If you decide "no, we won't support Work Queue pattern" then that's ok, we'll get back to our own implementation of that and oslo.messaging will become one of the possible implementations of our RPC layer (I predict some people may start laughing out loud at this point) along with other technology specific implementations such as RabbitMQ (via Pika or Kombu).

That's all from me.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-12-10 11:16:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified-1

Merge Failed.

This change or one of its cross-repo dependencies was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of its repository. Please rebase the change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2015-12-10 12:11:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

So to summarize:

I think that Renat and myself and several others agree on the general approach - add a new API to oslo.messaging. We all used several different names for it. I called it "ensure", Renat thinks "distribute" is a good name, but we are essentially talking about the same thing - adding a "worker queue" pattern abstraction to oslo.messaging.

As for the question whether this should be part of oslo.messaging or not in the first place - (I am not a oslo.messaging maintainer, so this is just my opinion), it's seems to be like this: There is obviously a need for it, but it really should be a technical call. oslo.messaging has quite a bit of complexity already, and it may be in the best interest of the library to punt on major features like this for the sake of internal cleanup. This is really up to the oslo.messaging community to decide.

I don't know the back story of why Mistral team got pushback on having their own implementation, but it seems it was not based on technical arguments which is not a good place to start such discussions from.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2015-12-10 23:30:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Out of curiosity what did the mini-work-queue code look like? (anywhere on github?)'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2016-02-29 17:28:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-2

The mitaka release is in feature freeze and only bug fixes for mitaka will be accepted until a stable branch is created. The -2 will be removed when a stable branch is created.'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2016-03-09 20:01:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: -Code-Review

This project is now open for new features.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2016-03-21 12:20:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: -Code-Review

Note, for Mistral it was implemented as https://review.openstack.org/#/c/279018'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2017-12-18 05:21:29.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Jenkins with the following votes:

* Verified-1 by Jenkins (3)
'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2018-03-22 00:58:13.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Allow explicit passing of what is or isn't optional

Instead of *only* trying to infer the optional arguments
by examining the function provided, make it so that just
like 'requires' and 'provides' the 'optional' values can
also be explicitly provided (for folks that like to do
just that).

Change-Id: I9640b00db32001a3697160fbf1e9a68bcd80d5d6

Just a minor usability question/suggestion.  Someone really wanted to change the scoping order?  The default is pretty logical.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2015-12-30 21:32:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

(1 comment)

So let me see if I can remember who wanted this change (arg, I should of asked them to file a bug/blueprint) but I think the desire was basically to be able to make the order the following (vs what it is):

   1. Injected atom providers
   2. Dynamic scope found providers
   3. Injected flow providers

The above matches slightly better to the functional concepts of 'local scope' (injected atom providers), 'nested scope' (dynamic scope found providers) and 'global scope' (injected flow providers)."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-01-04 03:56:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Verified-1

commit_message:
Allow customized scope lookup reordering

The current strategy of:

1. Injected atom providers
2. Injected flow providers
3. Dynamic scope found providers

Does not suit everyone's desires, so this addition
makes it possible to re-order that order into some other
order that the user may desire more than what the default
is.

Change-Id: I6c3f31477073aa575a342ebcc135db0710ba5ac2

commit_message:
Move bulk of storage '__init__' logic to new '_prepare' method

Constructors should not be doing that much work, so move the loading
of an existing injected values, mapping/caching to uuids and mapping/caching
failures to a new '_prepare' method instead and call it when the
storage object is created to make it easier to understand the various stages
of the storage '__init__' logic.

Change-Id: I5135ce649a647e3b30563fd5f44e1a06d40d9eee

commit_message:
Separate revert/execute failure into different outcome constants

Instead of depending on type checks to determine if a execute
or revert function failed use new outcome constants to better handle
and identify when revert/execute have really failed.

Change-Id: I83e3e31836e5ed3a60f4fa45a098af07a32112e5

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-06-26 01:07:02.000000000', 'message': "Allow regeneration of built-in matched python exceptions (WIP)

Instead of always re-raising a 'WrappedFailure' when we
have translated a failure into an dict and back again we
can attempt to safely regenerate the exception class and
a valid exception value from it instead (and only enable
this for exceptions that we explicitly match).

This allows for users to catch the native exception class
when running an engine (and especially when running a worker
or remote engine that does not run its tasks locally and
translates its failures into dictionaries, and back again).

Change-Id: Ie0e6bd5f3a9c1ff27cd3257270b238cf719d8398

commit_message:
Allow regeneration of built-in matched python exceptions

Instead of always re-raising a 'WrappedFailure' when we
have translated a failure into an dict and back again we
can attempt to safely regenerate the exception class and
a valid exception value from it instead (and only enable
this for exceptions that we explicitly match).

This allows for users to catch the native exception class
when running an engine (and especially when running a worker
or remote engine that does not run its tasks locally and
translates its failures into dictionaries, and back again).

Change-Id: Ie0e6bd5f3a9c1ff27cd3257270b238cf719d8398

commit_message:
Provide direct access to splits captured vs. returning a tuple

Oslo.concurrency has a lock timing function that can just use splits
but it needs to have easy access to the number of splits that have
been captured to do things differently if the number is
different; so add the ability to easily fetch how many splits
have been captured by just returning the underlying list (and updating
the docstring to denote it should only be used in a read-only
fashion).

This is a api change, that alters how the splits property now returns
a list, instead of a previous tuple, this should be harmless, or that
is the goal as the returned result is still recommended to be read-only
even after this change.

Change-Id: Ia5ada0d4a8cf4c0807212867c6d993b729063f6e

commit_message:
Allow destroying a specific flow detail of a given logbook (WIP)

It is quite useful to be able to remove a flow detail from
a logbook once the flow associated with that object has been
finished; so support a basic api that allows for this removal
to occur.

Change-Id: Ib3d6e3acb7117cb73f11ea84b8a7ddf6032a9889

commit_message:
Add ability to cancel an engine via a cancel method (WIP)

This also at the same time cleans up the states.py transitions
that are ignored, adding explanations to why certain ones are
ignored.

Change-Id: I7850820e3d8fba39e68a3eb058abd820a7cdfa06

commit_message:
Use singledispatch functions instead of isinstance checks

Using the singledispatch matching function(s) allows for those
function to be further optimized and moves the type checking
into the singledispatch routine instead of in the class.

Depends-On: Idb046b0e4e23af49c947a80cf6f77fef3a9ec0c8

Depends-On: I3c8ff515c29d8156ad114ba6dfb36bcfc68689e0

Change-Id: I2bf6208c8450213d3f80b27e1353fb442a3c8d86

So what happened with this one?  I remember you put it up after I brought it up.  Was there pushback or did it just fall through the cracks?  We haven't been having issues with this lately so maybe whatever problem we had was fixed by some other update, but I still think the idea of being able to control the timing of the job is a useful addition.  It would allow someone to build scheduled jobs on top of it pretty easily, although that can be a slippery slope to people wanting to replace cron.  Anyway, should we pick this up and finish it or throw it out?  I'm willing to do the work to finish it off, now that I have a somewhat better grasp on the internals."}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2016-02-29 18:45:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2

commit_message:
Avoid the writing to special task detail

Instead of writing flow symbols that are global to
the flow to a special task detail object, move to
writing that same data into the flow detail metadata
key with name '_TaskFlow_INJECTOR'.

This also activates/creates a routine that transfers
data from that existing atom detail on storage creation
to flow detail metadata on __init__ so that the existing
saved values still exist (until a point in the future
when we turn off this migration helper).

Change-Id: I047244a85546b394945cbb06db3ee43509614577

'}, {'created': '2015-02-19 23:30:12.000000000', 'message': 'WIP for having the ability to have tooz find/advertise workers

Instead of having a not very optimial worker capability discovery
process that involves periodic message queue pings/pongs we can
use the ability of the tooz library to maintain groups and information
about members that are in each group to expose that same information
in a more decoupled manner.

Part of blueprint wbe-worker-info

Part of blueprint use-tooz-for-membership

Change-Id: Icb43c345024ebd7845b8b02a9e0aeb3255bf2f1f
'}, {'created': '2015-02-20 02:56:18.000000000', 'message': 'Optionally use tooz and its group concepts to find/advertise workers

Instead of having a not very optimal (but good for a default) worker
capability discovery process that involves periodic message queue
pings/pongs we can use the ability of the tooz library to maintain groups
and information about members that are in each group to expose (and find)
that same information in a more decoupled manner.

Part of blueprint wbe-worker-info

Part of blueprint use-tooz-for-membership

Depends-On: Ibc745927eccac050992227410cca393d956f8c44

Change-Id: Icb43c345024ebd7845b8b02a9e0aeb3255bf2f1f
'}, {'created': '2015-02-20 04:37:07.000000000', 'message': 'Experimentally & optionally use tooz to find/advertise workers

Instead of having a not very optimal (but good for a default) worker
capability discovery process that involves periodic message queue
pings/pongs we can use the ability of the tooz library to maintain groups
and information about members that are in each group to expose (and find)
that same information in a more decoupled manner.

Part of blueprint wbe-worker-info

Part of blueprint use-tooz-for-membership

Depends-On: Ibc745927eccac050992227410cca393d956f8c44

Change-Id: Icb43c345024ebd7845b8b02a9e0aeb3255bf2f1f

commit_message:
Add ability to use tooz to find and advertise workers

Instead of having a not very optimal (but good for a default) worker
capability discovery process that involves periodic message queue
pings/pongs we can use the ability of the tooz library to maintain groups
and information about members that are in each group to expose (and find)
that same information in a more decoupled manner.

Part of blueprint wbe-worker-info

Part of blueprint use-tooz-for-membership

Change-Id: Icb43c345024ebd7845b8b02a9e0aeb3255bf2f1f

subject: Add *basic* scope visibility constraints

commit_message:
Add *basic* scope visibility constraints

Allow for a flow to mandate the visibility of its
contents (in terms of the flows internals providing
outputs to the inputs of further atoms that may look
for/use those named inputs).

The currently implemented types are:

- SCOPE_VISIBLE (the *default*, allows contained
  atoms/flows provided results to be visible to
  successors).
- SCOPE_HIDDEN (does not allow contained
  atoms/flows provided results to be visible to
  successors).

Part of blueprint taskflow-improved-scoping

Change-Id: Ibbeae69be2c8ffe3a54bf9e37ff80c0196d3e8e7

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-11-25 03:12:46.000000000', 'message': 'Allow for atoms to fail and execution to continue

Make it possible that a retry controller can inform the
runtime to just retain the failure but continue to execute
any other capable atoms. This allows users to provide this
and handle the failures post-runtime if they so choose to
do so.

Change-Id: I2911be0697bbbe8fbafa1eafe99bdee5fcba417d
'}]
commit_message:
Allow for atoms to fail and execution to continue

Make it possible that a retry controller can inform the
runtime to just retain the failure but continue to execute
any other capable atoms. This allows users to provide this
and handle the failures post-runtime if they so choose to
do so.

Change-Id: I2911be0697bbbe8fbafa1eafe99bdee5fcba417d

commit_message:
Allow nested flows to be unnamed/anonymous

Instead of requiring names for nested flows make it possible
so that nested flows can be unnamed (since with the current
compilation that exists the nested flows will be squashed and
lost anyway) so that users are able to avoid names if they
desire to (the root flow must be named, as that one is strongly
connected to a flow detail during execution).

Change-Id: I157a3722dac60a6117684b622c12f2d3335c9731

commit_message:
Allow endpoints to be fetched from factories

To make it possible to have more than simple lists
for endpoints make it so that the provided endpoints
that WBE workers can execute can be a factory like
concept.

These factories expose a get() method and a __iter__()
method that can be used be by others to fetch endpoints
from the factory and for others to use to notify others
about the endpoints the worker supports.

Change-Id: Ifef2d21bb9b00dfcdc417070682d2a7136885539

commit_message:
Work on a CAP section (WIP)

To describe the distributed system and model
that taskflow provides start adding a section
that analyzes how taskflow jobs, engines,
workers, .... fit in the three dimensions of
the CAP theorem.

Change-Id: Icd9cef5859f199bf50d353000ff3f8b5bfdca589

commit_message:
Make it possible to set the root logger level (not via debug)

Just allow people to provide logging levels for the root logger
and stop trying to mash our own set of debug or ... to
do the same thing.

Closes-Bug: #1620789

Change-Id: I9a9ee70ac591bb99f29af2693e184af60d80cfce

I love removing shenanigans!'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-03-19 15:05:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-03-20 10:26:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-03-21 14:52:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-03-21 14:53:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

I love that we can now remove the timestamp trick. It was brilliant but a little confusing, using the CREATED state to stop adding them to the SUM and knowing they will become active when ready makes life much better.

Great work!'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-12 20:26:44.000000000', 'message': "Remove unnecessary timestamp shenanigans when creating shard container

The root container must not use object stats from a newly created
shard container to which no objects have been cleaved. Those stats are
likely to be much lower than the shard's steady-state values.

Before, we avoided the root merging updates for newly created shards
by artificially winding the shard container's timestamp back so that
all updates from that container would be ignored until it received a
new timestamp via cleaving.

This timestamp trick is no longer necessary now that we have the
luxury of every container explicitly reporting its shard range
state. The root broker simply ignores shard ranges in CREATED state
when calculating object stats. When a shard range is cleaved to a
CREATED shard container its shard range moves to ACTIVE and the next
root update will propagate that change of state.

Change-Id: I0381a99ab265557f36a0fff09edf6711cc1e4d38

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary timestamp shenanigans when creating shard container

The root container must not use object stats from a newly created
shard container to which no objects have been cleaved. Those stats are
likely to be much lower than the shard's steady-state values.

Before, we avoided the root merging updates for newly created shards
by artificially winding the shard container's timestamp back so that
all updates from that container would be ignored until it received a
new timestamp via cleaving.

This timestamp trick is no longer necessary now that we have the
luxury of every container explicitly reporting its shard range
state. The root broker simply ignores shard ranges in CREATED state
when calculating object stats. When a shard range is cleaved to a
CREATED shard container its shard range moves to ACTIVE and the next
root update will propagate that change of state.

Change-Id: I0381a99ab265557f36a0fff09edf6711cc1e4d38

commit_message:
Fix hints update appear 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'update'

This patch fix hints update error, If scheduler_hints not configure
in create profile, the hints get 'None' value, the None not exist
update operation.

Change-Id: Id8ac13b9c190a4ece8d098837c47964059fd33fe
Signed-off-by: Yuanbin.Chen <cybing4@gmail.com>

commit_message:
QNAP Drivers - Move from httplib to requests

Use driver_ssl_cert_verify under backend section to
enable or disable SSL verfication.

NOTE: IPv6 isn't supported by QNAP driver.

Change-Id: Iba886fd0bd401052a444eb7a4427607e693d7c81
Closes-Bug: 1658766
Partial-Bug: 1188189

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-21 14:49:31.000000000', 'message': 'tasks: Ensure machinectl quota value is reasonable

It appears that when setting a limit which is greater than the size
of the underlying filesystem, machinectl does not change the quota at
all. As such, lets calculate the limit based on the /var/lib/machines
mountpoint or any of its parents.

Change-Id: I8ddc9931cbca5db8c1a411fd2581b34763179d01
(cherry picked from commit 345b501464880ecbb5d122d7715277cf1d0506c5)
'}]
commit_message:
tasks: Ensure machinectl quota value is reasonable

It appears that when setting a limit which is greater than the size
of the underlying filesystem, machinectl does not change the quota at
all. As such, lets calculate the limit based on the /var/lib/machines
mountpoint or any of its parents.

Change-Id: I8ddc9931cbca5db8c1a411fd2581b34763179d01
(cherry picked from commit 345b501464880ecbb5d122d7715277cf1d0506c5)

subject: tasks: Ensure machinectl quota value is reasonable

(cherry picked from commit 345b501464880ecbb5d122d7715277cf1d0506c5)
'}]
commit_message:
tasks: Ensure machinectl quota value is reasonable

It appears that when setting a limit which is greater than the size
of the underlying filesystem, machinectl does not change the quota at
all. As such, lets calculate the limit based on the /var/lib/machines
mountpoint or any of its parents.

Change-Id: I8ddc9931cbca5db8c1a411fd2581b34763179d01
(cherry picked from commit 345b501464880ecbb5d122d7715277cf1d0506c5)

commit_message:
Add logging for xmlsec1 installation

Keystone uses a library called xmlsec1 to create SAML assertions when
acting as an identity provider. If this library isn't present and
someone attempts to authenticate, keystone will throw an HTTP 500.
The only thing the error says is that a file or directory doesn't
exist.

This patch uses subprocess to check if the provided binary actually
exists on the system and handles cases when it isn't and logs a
useful message for operators.

Change-Id: I41cf87702df5389c1424d35f0abcef9c16301450
Closes-Bug: 1750917

Change-Id: Id9627839c38798704dbffac3b52dfd4c4046b598

commit_message:
Rename '_numa_get_constraints_XXX' functions

These don't actually return constraints but topologies. Rename and
group them together.

Change-Id: Id9627839c38798704dbffac3b52dfd4c4046b598

commit_message:
Re-add ceph NFS gateway disable settings

The vars to disable ceph's ganesha NFS gateway installation were
mistakenly removed in I243e742da3bf7d1e452998f257f7d0804e13237b.

The NFS gateway serves no purpose in an OSA installation and should
be disabled by default.

Change-Id: Iaf2667b7cbd63b6fee04075122a2a532471cf205

commit_message:
Remove the deprecated Pika driver

It is recommended that all users of the Pika driver transition to
using the Rabbit driver instead.  Typically this is done by changing
the prefix of the transport_url configuration option from "pika://..."
to "rabbit://...".  There are no changes required to the RabbitMQ
server configuration.

Change-Id: I52ea5ccb7e7c247abd95e2d8d50dac4c4ad11246
Closes-Bug: #1744741

commit_message:
Show Network Mask field when subnetpool is used

In the "Create Network" form and "Create Subnet" form, "Network Mask"
field was not shown when a subnet pool mode ("Allocate Network Address
from a pool") is selected as "Network Address Source".

Change-Id: Ieb6788a1301167ea7084a8c63462375426100e0a
Closes-Bug: #552247

commit_message:
Ingress: support arbitary hostnames.

This PS allows arbitary hostnames to be used for public endpoints,
provided the resolve externally to the ingress controllers.

Change-Id: I44411687f756968d00178d487af66c2393e6bde0

commit_message:
tox needs to pull from stable/queens

Updates the tox.ini to pull from nova's stable/queens branch
instead of master. This should have been done when we first
branched queens here, but was missed.

Change-Id: Ifdc23f94a8448e12252ce73a436fcf4049d4f7b3

subject: Support member_of param for allocation candidates
messages:
[{'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-02-14 21:08:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-02-14 21:19:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)

This spec doesn't say how aggregates get to the ?member_of= queryparameter.

And it shouldn't.

But it wouldn't hurt my feelings if it mentioned the possibilities (e.g. we could get 'em from flavors like we do for traits; or from conf as suggested in Dan's spec; or whatever) and stated that that's explicitly out of scope here.

In general, supportive of this idea; it'll be useful no matter how we decide to feed the aggregates in."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-02-14 21:25:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Eric, they get fed in via the changes proposed here:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/544585/

Which depend on this spec.'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2018-02-14 21:44:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

sounds sane enough'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-02-14 22:16:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Eric, they get fed in via the changes proposed here:

Yeah, I get that; what I'm asking for is explicit words in this spec saying that we're *not* nailing that down as the only mechanism we'll allow.  IOW via that spec we'll feed 'em one way; but some future effort may feed 'em in another way, and that's cool."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-02-15 10:56:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Local testing with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/543386/ shows we need to adjust the --templates & --work-dir logic of the client. It tries to search in the --templates dir the templates rendered in work-dir, and fails'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-12 13:12:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-12 13:15:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-12 13:17:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Workflow-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-12 13:23:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-12 13:33:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-02-12 17:48:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)

I have a question re the symlinking'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-13 08:24:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-13 08:39:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-13 08:44:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-02-13 14:07:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-13 15:17:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

I think the work dir for rendered templates needs to be persistent by default. Unlike to overcloud plan, we do not store it in swift. And being it removed by default, unless given the --no-cleanup option would provide poor UX. From the other side, it seems pointless adding --cleanup as well, as users will likely not use it by default and have templates saved for each run into temp dirs, which is what we want to go with by default (for better UX, as I noted above)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-13 15:26:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

the benefit of having it symlinked and persisted is prolly for dev and debug purposes. It's easier to explore templates than real nested heat structures (prolly). And it'd be easier to install updated t-h-t package then cd into a work dir and re-render in-place, no dances to copy once again"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2018-02-13 15:38:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

I think I prefer the copying approach that shardy suggest. As for persisting the --work-dir I'd be fine if it removed it by default. @James, I took the existing overcloud CLI option, --no-cleanup, to keep those streamlined. I was recommended to re-use it instead of adding a new one'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-21 08:17:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

For debug purposes, users should use --no-cleanup option IMO. By default, they are expected to not examine those rendered templates.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-21 08:25:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 18.'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2018-02-21 12:19:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18: Code-Review-1

> For debug purposes, users should use --no-cleanup option IMO. By
 > default, they are expected to not examine those rendered templates.

well, that is not how this should be used. anything Heat driven had better keep the templates around by default or we can't debug. this is critical. it's not like Heat is just an "implementation detail" here, the user is expected to interact with it via -e's.

keeping the templates around by default is just good practice and user friendly.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-02-21 12:28:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18:

> well, that is not how this should be used. anything Heat driven had better keep the templates around by default or we can't debug. this is critical

Well that's not how tripleoclient works for the overcloud, but obviously we have the plan with the rendered templates.

The thing is, the input to the deploy is the --templates tree, *not* the rendered tree, which will be replaced every deploy anyway, so IMO it *is* an implementation detail for non developers.

That said I won't block on it, if folks want us to leak temporary directories every CLI action like with config download then fair enough."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-22 09:52:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18: Workflow-1

We need as well to make those added --no-cleanup and --output-dir available for undercloud deploy either via conf file or via CLI args'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-22 11:04:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 19.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-22 11:14:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-22 11:25:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 20.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-22 11:32:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-22 11:37:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 21.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-22 14:24:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 22.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-22 14:26:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 23.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-22 14:27:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-22 14:36:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 24.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-22 15:00:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 25.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-02-22 15:05:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 26.'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2018-02-22 21:56:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 26: Code-Review+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-09 15:11:53.000000000', 'message': 'Prepare t-h-t for undercloud in a work dir

The issue here is that the undercloud heat installer
default uses template in /usr/share and renders the
result of the process-templates.py in place.

Add an optional --work-dir, the persistent work dir
for the Heat templates including those rendered from
the --templates dir. By default, it is a temporary
directory under /var/tmp/ rendered from templates installed
from the t-h-t package.

Depends-on: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/542833

Change-Id: Ib0c2e3ffd81742441400d27857afae457d71a424
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-02-09 15:20:49.000000000', 'message': 'Prepare t-h-t for undercloud in a work dir

The issue here is that the undercloud heat installer
default uses template in /usr/share and renders the
result of the process-templates.py in place.

Add an optional --work-dir, the persistent work dir
for the Heat templates including those rendered from
the --templates dir. By default, it is a temporary
directory under /var/tmp/ rendered from templates installed
from the t-h-t package.

Additional changes:
  - fix tox errors for undercloud_backup
  - refactor symlinks into a function to not repeat itself
    and to be more safe on teardown

Depends-on: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/542833

Change-Id: Ib0c2e3ffd81742441400d27857afae457d71a424
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
